The study used task-based fMRI to assess theory of mind, a social cognitive process, in younger and older adult participants. It reports healthy participant groups and a social-related task, matching the review objective. Although exact ages are not provided, the presence of a younger adult group implies inclusion of participants likely within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of action observation/execution examining how observers process others’ effort—fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social processing. Involves human participants performing/observing a task. Abstract does not report ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health; not a review/meta-analysis.

Participants are preschool-aged children (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65. No group of healthy adult participants is present, so study does not meet inclusion criteria for adult fMRI social-processing studies.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social gaze-following task examining social attention and ideological/in-group effects. Meets review objective (social processing in fMRI) and inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Empirical fMRI study investigating neural systems for social cognition/action understanding in human participants; not a review. Tasks involved social cognitive processes (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems). No evidence of clinical populations; likely healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification of participant ages and details.

Primary empirical fMRI study in human participants performing a social cognition task (comparing romantic partner and roommate), addressing perception/understanding of others. Likely healthy adult sample, not a review or meta-analysis — meets inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in a sample of multiple sclerosis patients with no mention of a healthy control group; no task-based social processing was performed. Does not meet inclusion criteria requiring task-based fMRI and at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

fMRI study of a social-related task (Theory of Mind) including a healthy control group. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, the study involves adult participants and is not a review, so it meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are children (ages 9–13), which does not meet the review’s age inclusion criterion of 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI on social cognition, the sample age clearly excludes it from this review.

Study used BOLD fMRI in healthy participants performing affective and cognitive Theory of Mind tasks (social processing). While ages are not stated, the abstract describes healthy adult participants; insufficient age detail for final determination, so include for full-text review to confirm age and details.

Primary fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs competitive interactions in humans. Published empirical NeuroImage article with healthy adult participants implied; meets inclusion of social-related task during fMRI. Not a review; include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study in healthy adult participants using a social interaction task (provocation/retaliation) relevant to social processing. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adult group). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports fMRI connectivity in high-functioning adolescents with ASD versus typically developing adolescents, but does not state participant ages or whether an active social-related task was used (could be resting-state). Because the abstract lacks key information about healthy participants meeting the 17–65 age criterion and task relevance, include for full-text review.

Study uses fMRI to examine effects of an implied social presence on brain networks linked to social cognition/theory of mind, matching the review’s social-processing objective. Abstract implies human participants and functional connectivity measures but does not specify ages or explicit task details; information is insufficient to confirm all inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65.

Event-related fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social cognition task involving empathy/understanding of others) that includes a healthy control group matched for age. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a social-related task. Although healthy controls were included, the review requires task-based fMRI during social processing; the abstract clearly describes resting-state functional connectivity, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy young adult men (n=55) performing social-related tasks (attachment/erotic and fearful social scenes); meets inclusion criteria (social processing, age range, healthy participants). Not a review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (ABIDE data) comparing ASD and controls; no task-based social processing paradigm is used. The review requires task fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion.

fMRI was used while participants performed social-related tasks (IAT on attitudes toward adultery, go/no-go and date-rating assessing interest in unfamiliar potential partners), involving affiliation/attachment and social perception; participants are healthy adult males in relationships; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy human adults investigating perception of others' head-turn direction—a dynamic social attention cue—using multivariate pattern analysis in STS. Fits social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study focused on cerebro-cerebellar limbic connectivity in MCI/AD patients (and controls). It does not involve a social-related task or social processing in healthy adults, so it fails the task-based social-processing inclusion criterion.

fMRI study probes social cognition (mentalizing/perception of others) during listening to literary fiction, matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy status; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 17–65 and healthy).

Study used fMRI to examine implicit facial emotion recognition, which is a social-processing task. The sample is described as subjects with high genetic load for schizophrenia; abstract does not clearly state clinical status or ages, so inclusion of healthy adults is uncertain. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants (age 17–65) and task details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in which pairs of friends performed a social-sharing task while one underwent fMRI; it examines social/affiliation processing and reports neural activation (ventral striatum, mOFC). Participants are healthy friends (implied adults) and this is an original empirical study, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria; age not specified in abstract but inclusion allows inclusion for full-text review if unclear.

fMRI study presenting dynamic and static facial expressions (social stimuli) assessing perception/processing of others’ emotions. Includes age- and sex-matched typically developing controls (healthy participants). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits social-processing task and healthy adult group inclusion criteria.
Participants are 4- and 6-year-old children with no healthy adult (age 17–65) group reported. Does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy adults.

Study used real-time fMRI while volunteers played the ultimatum game (a social interaction/economic decision-making task), fitting social-related processing. Participants are described as volunteers (presumably healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study reports an fMRI task addressing body checking (self-perception), which could fit the review’s social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self). However, the abstract only mentions females with anorexia nervosa and does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because participant-group information is insufficient to determine eligibility, include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy human participants performing a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma). Addresses social processing constructs; participants described as healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

This article is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies on social-cognitive deficits after traumatic brain injury. It is a meta-analysis/systematic review rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used functional MRI while adults (including a matched healthy control group) considered social interactions, directly addressing social-related processing. At least one healthy adult group is present and age range fits. Not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

The abstract reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants examining perception of in-group vs out-group actions — a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). Participants were divided into teams; neural mechanisms were measured during the task. This meets the inclusion criteria (fMRI, social-related processing, healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract discusses fMRI and example attempts but does not report clear methods, participant ages, or actual fMRI data in healthy adults. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; full-text review needed to determine if primary fMRI study with healthy adults was conducted.

fMRI study of joint attention and representing another person’s visual contents—clearly a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Imaging and task meet inclusion; participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age/health criteria.

fMRI study investigated face emotion discrimination (a social-cognition task) in a community sample comparing high vs low social anhedonia; participants are healthy adults and task probes social processing. Study is empirical (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using point-light displays of biological motion—a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others; reports cerebro-cerebellar connectivity relevant to social cognitive processing. Abstract implies healthy participants but does not state ages, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of social cognition (irony comprehension) with 15 healthy female controls and 15 patients; meets criterion of at least one group of healthy participants performing a social-related task. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

Healthy comparison group consists of adolescents (study focuses on adolescents); inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65 (adults). Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=55 males) performing a social-related task (direct vs. averted gaze). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI BOLD study with 25 healthy adult female participants performing a social-cognitive task about kin and friends; directly examines social cognition constructs and meets inclusion criteria (healthy adults, task-based fMRI). Not a review.

fMRI study in humans using empathy-evoking film clips assessing social cognition (empathic concern) and neural connectivity. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state 'healthy', so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI study of empathy/perspective-taking (social cognition) in eighteen healthy participants; task involves perception/understanding of others (pain empathy). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
Participants are children (mean age 10.2 years), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although an fMRI social-processing task was used, the sample age fails the inclusion criterion.

Abstract describes fMRI of negative emotion processing but does not state a social-related task or clearly specify healthy adult sample. Insufficient information to rule in/out inclusion; per instructions include for full-text review.

fMRI study of action understanding engaging mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks (social cognition). Participants performed a social-related task (why/how judgments about actions). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not state ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study examining brain activity during observation of social interactions and gaze, addressing social cognition (Perception/Understanding of Others). Abstract indicates a task during scanning and implies healthy participants (no clinical sample reported). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study directly examining neural processing of social versus nonsocial gestures (social cognition constructs). However, the abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social interactive task vs a non-social control, examining social cognition networks in human subjects. This meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adult subjects (no indication of patient groups) and it is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Study used fMRI during the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (social cognition/emotion recognition) in 16 healthy young adult women, meeting the social-related task and healthy adult participant criteria. Not a review; inclusion appropriate based on abstract.

Study reports task-based fMRI during social cognition (theory of mind) and executive tasks, includes an age-matched healthy control group, and involves adult participants. No exclusion criteria met; suitable for full-text review for eligibility confirmation.

fMRI study of self-referential processing (a social-related construct) that includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients. The abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study presenting the EmpaToM task that independently manipulates empathy and Theory of Mind in healthy adult samples (N=90 and N=178). It investigates social cognitive processes (empathy, ToM) with task-based fMRI and reports neural–behavior relations. Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports human fMRI examining voice processing, which is social communication/perception of others. It uses task-based fast fMRI showing voice-sensitive auditory cortex responses. No exclusion criteria are met. Participant health and exact ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

Original fMRI study using MVPA examining neural representation of others' mental states (social cognition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages/health not stated in abstract, typical sample likely healthy adults; study clearly addresses social-related processing with fMRI, so include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI following intranasal oxytocin in healthy volunteers and did not report any task or task-based social processing. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring functional MRI during a social-related task.

fMRI study of adolescents viewing parent videos (social stimuli) assessing neural responses linked to social cognition; participants mean age 17 (within 17–65 criterion) and appear healthy. Study addresses social processing in humans and is not a review.

fMRI study investigating effects of social gaze on action control using a social vs nonsocial stimulus-response task. Involves healthy adult participants and examines social-related processing (social gaze, social cognition). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Study II reports an fMRI scan during an interactive social gaze paradigm and includes a healthy control group (16 controls). The task assesses social reward/interaction processing, matching the review constructs. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Abstract addresses theory-of-mind/mentalization (social processing) and discusses functional neuroimaging of the mPFC; however, it does not explicitly state methods, participant details, or that fMRI was performed on healthy adults. Insufficient methodological detail in abstract to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify fMRI during a social task and participant characteristics.

Participants are children with benign childhood epilepsy (BCECTS), not healthy adults aged 17–65; study examines a clinical pediatric population, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of healthy adult participants.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no social-related task performed). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social processing task; although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22). Task involved observing others’ risk-taking vs safe actions, addressing social perception/understanding and emotional/social cognition. Fits age range (17–65) and social-related processing criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study of emotional face processing (explicit vs implicit emotion recognition), a social perception/communication task, in 29 healthy participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract but participants are described as healthy adults—include for full-text verification of exact ages and other details.

fMRI study in normal adult volunteers viewing videos of positive/negative social encounters — directly assesses social processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.
Sample consists of adolescents aged 9–17 (N=34) with no separate healthy adult group within the required 17–65 age range. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion for healthy adults.

fMRI study examining neural representations of self (social cognition) across cultures using healthy adult participants; meets criterion of functional MRI during a social-related task (self-processing). Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (viewing others in pain; perception/understanding of others). Age range appears to be adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 22 healthy adult participants examining CT-targeted affective touch (social touch). The task probes social perception and social cognition (affiliation/attachment, perception of others); not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI study examining self- and other-related social cognition; includes a healthy control group (adult controls) contrasted with BPD participants. Meets inclusion: social-related fMRI task and presence of healthy adults aged within range. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining processing of different laughter types (social communication) with implicit/explicit task manipulations in human participants. Investigates social-related perception and neural connectivity; not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, but clearly meets the social-related fMRI task criterion — include for full-text to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

The study uses fMRI during self- and other-reflection, which are social-related processes relevant to the review. The abstract does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included; insufficient information to confirm, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Task-based fMRI in 25 healthy adult participants examining facial color processing, a social-communication cue relevant to perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies in healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI study examining neural correlates of self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluation—clearly a social-cognition task (Perception and Understanding of Self). Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status; information is insufficient to confirm sample fits 17–65 healthy criteria, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Participants are adult male incarcerated offenders; the abstract does not indicate any healthy control/healthy participant group. Meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults (age 17–65), so this study does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition is relevant, but abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criterion; include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants and ages.

fMRI was conducted while participants played an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma — a social decision-making task probing cooperation/trust. Study used 20 healthy adult male participants (within 17–65) in a placebo-controlled crossover design. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; not a review.

Abstract reports collection of simultaneous fMRI during a social interaction (a deception game between pairs), indicating an fMRI social-related task in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

fMRI study with 18 healthy adult participants performing a social motor response learning task that involves social interaction and inference about others’ intentions (mirror-neuron/frontal operculum). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI to examine Theory of Mind (a social cognition/Perception and Understanding of Others task) and explicitly included healthy comparison subjects. It therefore meets the fMRI + social-related task criteria and includes a healthy adult group, so it should be included for full review.

Original fMRI study examining multimodal perception of nonverbal emotional signals (voice and face), a social-related processing task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study in human participants performing a social cognition task (forming/updating impressions of others). No indication it is a review; likely healthy adult participants. Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of neural responses to facial expressions (social processing). Includes a healthy control group (no family history of autism). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and eligibility.

fMRI data collected while participants performed a social-perception task (perceiving/sex-categorizing interacting person dyads). Study involves social-related neural processing in (presumably) healthy adults and is an original fMRI study, not a review. Age range not reported in abstract; include for full-text verification.

Study used fMRI with an eyes task targeting Theory of Mind/social cognition, matching the review focus. Abstract does not specify ages or whether a healthy adult group (17–65) was included. Insufficient participant info—include for full-text screening to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining processing of emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception of others) in human participants. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Event-related fMRI study of healthy adults assessing trustworthiness of faces (social perception of others). Task is social-related; not a review. Abstract indicates neural responses during social judgment, meeting inclusion criteria. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Task-free (resting-state) fMRI study examining anterior temporal lobe connectivity with the language network in healthy adults; no social-related task or social processing measures described, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of a task-based social fMRI.

Uses fMRI during a social-perception task (point-light biological motion vs scrambled), examines neural systems for perception/understanding of others. Includes an adult sample and appears to study healthy participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports a neuroimaging study of interpersonal synchrony (a social/affiliation task) with healthy adult participants and identifies brain areas implicated in social cognition. Imaging modality (fMRI) and exact participant ages are not explicitly stated in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm that functional MRI was used and that participants meet the age/health criteria.

Abstract reports task-related fMRI during a social perception experiment and includes a healthy control group (21 adults). It directly addresses social-related processing and is an original fMRI study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

Primary data fMRI study using hyperscanning while participants performed joint-attention tasks (social cognitive processing). Involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and directly assesses perception/understanding of others; not a review or meta-analysis.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of human dyads performing a joint-attention social task—directly addresses social processing in interaction. Appears to involve healthy participants and fits the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or full sample details, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

Resting-state fMRI study with obese patients and lean controls; no social-related task was performed. Although the abstract mentions regions linked to social cognition, it does not test social processing in a task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

The article is a review of seven structural/functional MRI studies in ADHD samples, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a review paper (excluded per exclusion criteria) and the participant groups are clinical (ADHD), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no social-related task) conducted in male adolescents, including a conduct disorder group and typically developing adolescents. It does not include healthy adult participants aged 17–65 performing a social task, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task), so it does not assess neural responses during a social-related task. Although healthy controls were included, the inclusion criteria require task-based fMRI of social processing; therefore exclude.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of laughter perception (social communication/social cognition) in humans. While participant ages and health status are not specified, the study clearly examines social-related processing; include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health criteria.

fMRI study investigating Theory of Mind (perception/understanding of others) using an active task in human participants; not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects; include for full-text to confirm ages.

fMRI study examining integration of speaker characteristics and sentence content—core social communication/perception processes. Includes a matched healthy adult control group (adults), meeting age criterion. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info that the task is social-related and that healthy participants were scanned.

fMRI study in healthy adult mothers viewing own vs unfamiliar child/dog—task probes affiliation/attachment and social processing. Participants are adults within the target age range and it is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

Task-based fMRI study of self-reference vs. reference to others, directly addressing social cognition (perception/understanding of self and others). Abstract reports human fMRI data but does not specify participant health status or ages. Because the social-related task is clearly present but participant details are insufficient in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) in healthy adults; inclusion requires a task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of real-time mutual eye contact — a social interaction task (perception/understanding of others/social communication). Participants were healthy adult pairs (16 pairs, ages within 17–65 implied). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural responses to third-person social interactions (perception/understanding of others). Participants performed tasks while viewing social biological motion; not a review. Abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, but meets review topic—include for full-text confirmation of healthy adult sample and age range.
Participants are adolescents (ages 12–15), outside the required adult age range (17–65). No healthy adult group is reported. Although this is an fMRI social task, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (28 women, ages within 17–65) performing a social perception task (viewing animations of social interactions). Reports neural responses during social vs. size attention contrasts. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed an empathy-for-pain task (viewing painful vs. control stimuli), which is social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a group of healthy young adults aged 20–30 (within the 17–65 inclusion age range). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of framing in evaluations of personal attributes—clearly a social-cognition/self-perception task. Abstract describes use of healthy participants (no clinical groups reported) but does not state ages; insufficient age/health detail for final determination, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=21) performing an affective theory-of-mind task (inferring others' emotions from stories and facial expressions), which is social cognition/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of social understanding/social processing; includes a matched healthy adult control group (23 adults) alongside ASD participants. Participants described as adults (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, and focuses on schizophrenia (clinical group). It does not report fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are healthy children and adolescents aged 10–17 with no adult-only group within the target age range (17–65). The meta-analysis requires fMRI data from healthy adults (17–65); this study focuses on minors, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants performing a Theory-of-Mind (social cognition) task (REMICS). Investigates social processing (mental state inference/contextual adjustment). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where healthy participants viewed animated characters making angry vs. happy expressions — a clear social-perception/communication task (perception/understanding of others). No indication this is a review or that participants were non-healthy. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted during an interactive mentalizing (social cognition) task; the study includes a healthy typically-developed control group (ages 18–34) meeting the 17–65 criterion. Abstract states participants were 'adolescents' (typically developing adolescents and those with ASD). No healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported, so the study does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group.

Participants are children aged 7–12 years; inclusion criterion requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI and examines social processing, the sample does not meet the age range, so it should be excluded.

The study used resting-state fMRI collected after cTBS, not an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although the targeted SI relates to action observation/execution, no task-based social processing was performed during scanning, so it fails the inclusion criterion.

Participants are patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (a-MCI); the abstract does not report any healthy adult (17–65) group. Although the task involves social/emotional processing (face-name associations), the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group is not met.

Not a human task-based fMRI study: this is an animal (rat) resting-state fMRI study under anesthesia with no social-related task and participants are not human adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining cortical responses to vocal vs nonvocal sounds (socially relevant auditory processing). Abstract does not explicitly state presence/age range of healthy adult participants, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants performing naturalistic movie-viewing that probes social interaction processing (DMPFC responses). This directly addresses social cognition in healthy adults and is an original empirical fMRI report (not a review).

Abstract reports fMRI in 13 patients with PTSD with pre/post-therapy scans; no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is described. Does not meet criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group.

Study reports task-based functional MRI (dual-fMRI) during social interactions (cooperation vs. competition), directly addressing social processing. Abstract reports fMRI in patients with psychotic disorder; no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is mentioned. Meta-analysis requires at least one healthy participant group, so exclude.

fMRI study examining mirror neuron responses and emotion processing—central to social cognition (perception/understanding of others). fMRI social perspective-taking task performed; includes a typically developing (healthy) participant group. Insufficient age information — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study examining empathy/self–other representation (social processing: perception/understanding of others). fMRI study of face processing (social perception/understanding of others) with healthy control group (21 adults) and a clinical group; task is social-related (encoding/recognition of faces). Not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed prayer, a social-related task; results report recruitment of social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus). Task-based fMRI study using a validated Theory of Mind (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) social-cognition task in healthy adult volunteers (right-handed males). fMRI study examining cortical responses to faces (neutral and fearful), addressing perception/understanding of others — a social-processing task. fMRI study measuring brain responses while participants read a literary text; results report activation in medial frontal and temporo-parietal regions linked to social cognition and predictive inference. fMRI study manipulating sociality and social working memory (n-back) in humans; targets social cognition/face processing (perception/understanding of others). Likely healthy adult participants and not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining perception of facial and vocal emotional expressions (social communication/perception of others). No indication it is a review; participants appear to be healthy adults. fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (IAT with faces/names of politicians) and reported neural activations in social brain regions (vmPFC, amygdala, PFC, fusiform). Include for full-text review to confirm participant health status and ages.

fMRI study of causal attributions and self-serving bias during attributional decision tasks (social cognition: perception/understanding of self). Abstract refers to ‘normal subjects’ (healthy adults). Not a review—meets inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI neuroimaging study examining perception of social interactions (observing two agents), a social-related task in humans. Randomized within-subject pharmaco-fMRI in 40 adult males assessing neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch (a social communication task). fMRI study in 19 healthy volunteers performing social-evaluative tasks (guilt and embarrassment), examining neural substrates of social cognition/ToM. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during social-related task in healthy adults. Not a review.

Study uses face-processing (a social task) and likely fMRI, but abstract only mentions adults with Asperger syndrome and does not state inclusion of a healthy control group. Insufficient information about presence/age of healthy participants; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social task (learning others' trustworthiness/mentalizing). The study used only forensic inpatient participants (psychotic offenders and nonpsychotic offenders) and does not include a group of healthy adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task) in healthy males to examine oxytocin effects on connectivity. Does not involve an fMRI social-related task or social processing, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a mentalizing task (social cognition: understanding self/other) with adult participants; includes a healthy control group of adults (age-matched Controls). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are children (Korean children with ASD and typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although fMRI and social/pragmatic language tasks are used, the sample does not include healthy adult participants meeting the review age criterion.

fMRI study probing social processes (mimicry modulated by emotions and group membership) in human participants; directly relevant to social cognition. Narrative comparative review of face perception across species that summarizes behavioral and fMRI findings; not an original fMRI study conducting social-related tasks in healthy adult human participants. Does not meet inclusion criteria for primary human fMRI studies.

fMRI study examining social cognition (perception of cooperative behavior/theory of mind) with a healthy control group (19 matched controls). Task is social-related; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of affiliative (social) processing using kinship-related social scenarios in humans; not a review/meta-analysis; appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Title indicates a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (a meta-analytic approach) rather than a primary fMRI study with participants performing a social task. Exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses is met.

Abstract describes an fMRI gaze-contingent study of joint attention (a social process) but focuses on adolescents with autism. It does not clearly state inclusion of a healthy adult group aged 17–65. Event-related fMRI using the false belief paradigm investigates understanding others' mental states (Perception and Understanding of Others). Appears to involve healthy adult subjects and meets inclusion (social-related fMRI task). Not a review. Include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study in human adults examining self-, friend-, and unfamiliar-person face and name recognition (perception/understanding of self/others), fitting social-processing constructs. Participants were domestic dogs, not human adults. The review requires functional MRI studies with human participants (ages 17–65). Although it uses fMRI for social-related face perception, the non-human sample clearly excludes it.

fMRI was used while adult participants (healthy control group and ASD group) viewed dynamic emotional facial expressions, a social perception/understanding-of-others task. Abstract does not report any fMRI/functional neuroimaging or an fMRI task; it investigates genetic-environment interactions and response inhibition in adolescents. fMRI study examining neural responses to learned social roles using a social interaction (cyber-ball) and face-perception task—addresses social processing in humans. fMRI study in young healthy participants performing an incentive delay task with social rewards; investigates neural correlates of social reward anticipation and feedback (social-related processing). fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants examining co-speech gestures and semantic processing—addresses social communication (social-related processing). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for the review.

Abstract does not describe any social-related task during fMRI; it reports network/semi-metric analysis related to familial risk for psychotic disorder. fMRI study of emotion recognition (social cognition) including a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age and details.

Study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) rather than functional MRI. Although it examines social interaction in healthy adults, it does not meet the requirement of an fMRI scan during a social task.

Abstract does not state that an fMRI was used or that healthy adult control group (age 17–65) were included. Study focuses on autism but provides insufficient methodological detail; therefore include for full-text review to determine whether fMRI social-task data in healthy adults are reported.

Title indicates evaluation of face approachability (a social judgment) and reports brain responses, suggesting fMRI during a social task in healthy adults. fMRI study examining charitable donation/altruism and neural substrates of social attachment and aversion—clearly social-related processing. Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports only schizophrenia outpatients randomized to intervention or placebo; no group of healthy adults is described. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of including at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

Abstract reports neural (medial prefrontal) responses to social interaction images, indicating an fMRI social-related task. fMRI study using a social interaction simulation probing friendship-related processes (affiliation, reward, empathy) in 28 human participants. The task clearly targets social processing. fMRI study examining self-conscious emotion/social evaluation using a camera-watching task — a social-related task. The sample includes adults (in addition to children/adolescents) and appears to be healthy participants, meeting inclusion criteria for full-text review.

fMRI study of cross-modal face and voice perception (social communication/perception of others) with 20 participants; appears to involve healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports a single-case (n=1) fMRI study. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (implying >1). Because this is a single-subject report, it does not meet the sample/group criterion.

Event-related fMRI study of vocal emotional prosody, which targets social communication/perception of others. fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=26) performing a social learning task (inferring others' generosity). Directly investigates social cognition processes with task-based fMRI and is not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (mimicry modulated by direct eye contact). fMRI study examining neural correlates of verbal irony and Theory of Mind, a social-cognitive process (perception/understanding of others). Involves human participants and is not a review. Resting-state fMRI study (no social task performed) and focuses on ultra-high-risk-for-psychosis subjects rather than a task-based sample of healthy adults; does not meet inclusion criterion of fMRI during a social-related task.

Abstract text not provided; title indicates study of Asperger's syndrome but does not specify whether fMRI social tasks were used or whether healthy adult controls (17–65) were included. Insufficient information to exclude; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study used fMRI during a social-related task (social reflection/self vs others) in a group of 22 healthy participants. It directly addresses social processing in healthy adults; age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Participants are children (boys), including a child with autism and a typically developing child; no healthy adult (age 17–65) participant group is included. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of at least one healthy adult group for this review.

Event-related fMRI study of eye-gaze processing (a social cognition task). Abstract reports a group of typically developing subjects (healthy controls) in addition to autism group. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and eligibility.

Event-related fMRI study of person perception/violations of social expectations (social cognition/mentalizing). Task is social-related; not a review. fMRI study of social processing (multiple-round trust games) with an explicit healthy control group (20 subjects). Not a review. Ages not stated in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and extract task contrasts.

fMRI was conducted while healthy young adults (n=50) performed a social task (labeling briefly presented emotional facial expressions), which assesses perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy and within the eligible age range; study is original empirical research, not a review.

fMRI study using dynamic face processing (social stimuli), which fits social-related task criterion. fMRI task examines social processing (self vs others’ responses, social communication/understanding) and reports neural results. fMRI study of prosocial decision-making (social cognition/mentalizing) in healthy adult participants (n=25). Task involves social-related processing (family support), fits inclusion age range and criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study measuring neural responses to empathy-inducing campaign videos in 20 healthy volunteers; addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Fits review objective. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and other details.

FMRI was used to study event simulation, a process the authors link to social cognition (mentalizing/trait inference). The study appears to use healthy adult participants. The abstract lacks details on participant ages and whether tasks explicitly engaged social processing, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication/embodiment) in humans; not a review. Abstract implies empirical fMRI data and neural correlates in healthy participants. Meets review objective and inclusion criteria; full text can confirm ages if needed.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adult participants viewing faces of political candidates—clearly a social perception/understanding-of-others task (social-related processing). Sample comprises healthy registrants (Democrats/Republicans). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI investigation of social-related processing (affective theory of mind) and neural activation, but does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study with healthy young adults performing a social attribution task (perception/understanding of others). Directly addresses social processing; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

Abstract describes resting-state and unspecified task fMRI analyses but does not mention any social-related tasks or participant details. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm whether tasks involve social processing and participants are healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI (ALFF and RSFC) without any task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task; therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria despite its relevance to self-perception.

fMRI study examining neural responses during social communication/influence (mentalizing and reward systems) — clearly a social-related task. Abstract does not report participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm that at least one group are healthy adults aged 17–65.

Original fMRI research in healthy adult participants assessing neural responses to social reputation (a social-processing task). Participants include males and females; task probes perception/valuation of others’ social feedback. Study is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social contingency (self-relevant social reward) in adults; includes a healthy (typically-developing) control group of age-matched adults (n=24). Task assesses social-related processing (self/others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of gaze following—a social perceptual/communication task—meeting the review objective. Participant health status/ages (17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion requires full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study manipulating direct vs averted gaze (a social-processing task) including a healthy control group (n=16 adults) alongside a PTSD group; meets inclusion criteria and is an original empirical study rather than a review.

Abstract describes fMRI paradigms using real-time gaze-contingent stimuli to create interactive social tasks and reports results from two paradigms. It is not a systematic review. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text is needed to confirm sample meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study with 16 healthy adult male participants performing an interactive social task (competitive reaction-time provoking/retaliation) probing perception of others and social/affective processing (mPFC responses). Fits social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task; absence of a task means it does not meet the inclusion criteria despite including healthy postpartum women and examining social-related networks.

Participants are children (siblings, control children, and children with autism); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is reported. Therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.
Study samples early adolescents (development during adolescence) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review objective; therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of causal attribution to self/others/situation — a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of self and others). Sample: 20 typical (healthy) participants (adult population). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI in healthy adult participants to measure amygdala responses while viewing ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social perception/understanding of others task. Meets inclusion criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info.

Study targets social communication (right pSTS) using simultaneous EEG-fMRI/neurofeedback, which matches review objective. Abstract does not clearly state the exact task, participant health status, or ages. Insufficient detail to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm task and sample.

Study used resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than functional MRI acquired while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; therefore this study does not meet the key inclusion criterion.
Participants are boys aged 11–16 (adolescents), not adults aged 17–65; no healthy adult group is included. Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion in this review.

fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game (a social decision-making task assessing cooperation/affiliation). Randomized longitudinal design with healthy adult participants implied; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study using a facial affect matching task (social processing) and includes a healthy adult comparison group alongside methamphetamine-dependent participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study reports fMRI in 17 young adults with high-functioning ASD only; no healthy control group is mentioned. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, and participants are adolescent males (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Thus it does not meet the meta-analysis requirements for task-based social fMRI in adults.

The study samples pediatric/unaffected youth (adolescents), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although it uses fMRI on a social task (face emotion processing), the abstract does not report a healthy adult group within the required age range, so it fails the age/participant inclusion criterion.

Empirical fMRI study investigating perception of face identity and eye gaze—both social-communication/perception of others constructs—in human participants. Appears to involve healthy adult subjects and is primary research (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was conducted during facial emotion and age judgments, a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Study includes community control group of healthy adults. Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and extract details.
Participants were children aged 7–10, whereas the review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. The study therefore does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using a virtual-reality direct vs averted gaze task — a social communication/perception paradigm — that includes a healthy comparison group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion; full text can confirm participant ages if needed.

fMRI study of responses to social (emotional facial) stimuli; includes a control group compared with Williams syndrome participants, indicating presence of (presumably healthy) participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI and is not a review. Age not specified in abstract, but presence of control group supports inclusion for full-text review.

Primary study used fMRI during a task involving perception and memory for emotional facial expressions (angry vs happy/neutral), which is social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). It reports original data (not a review) and involves human participants consistent with healthy adult samples. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

fMRI study investigating audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional signals (social communication/perception of others) in human participants; aligns with social-related processing objective. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages—insufficient detail on age, so include for full-text screening to confirm participants meet 17–65 criterion.

fMRI study (n=16) examining incidental priming of participants’ own promotion/prevention goals—relates to social cognition (perception/understanding of self). Appears to use healthy adult participants; ages not reported in abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status and extract neural findings.

fMRI study examining evaluation of others' behavior (social cognition), matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health status.

fMRI study examining mothers’ brain responses to emotional expressions of their own children — a social/attachment-related task in adult participants. No indication study is a review or that participants are non-healthy; fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy adult players performing an action anticipation task involving perception and understanding of others’ actions (social processing domain). No clinical populations indicated. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining mirror neuron activity during observation of hand actions (social-related processing: empathy, perspective-taking). Includes both alexithymic and non-alexithymic adult groups (healthy participants). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social task in adults; not a review.

fMRI study using a face-discrimination task (social perception of others) and includes an age- and gender-matched healthy adult control group. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring brain responses while participants viewed emotional faces, which targets social perception/understanding of others. No indication participants had disorders; fits healthy adult sample likely within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed stigmatized individuals (a social-cognition task assessing perception/understanding of others and emotion regulation). The study includes healthy young adults (within 17–65) alongside older adults. It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, thus meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (10 males) performing a humor appreciation task (funny vs non-funny cartoons) which relates to social communication processing. Examines neural correlates of a social/personality trait (cheerfulness). Not a review and fits age/healthy-participant criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI of social processing and includes healthy participants, but sample are described as adolescents/youth and the abstract does not specify ages. Because adult age eligibility (17–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine age eligibility and other details.

Event-related fMRI measured brain responses during viewing of animations designed to manipulate intentionality/agency attribution—this is social perception/understanding of others. Participants appear to be healthy adults and the study is empirical (not a review). Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations (social communication). Abstract reports human fMRI data and is not a review. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility and details.

fMRI study of biological motion perception (a social-cognition task). Abstract does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review to confirm presence/ages of healthy participants.

Human fMRI study of empathic decision-making (social processing/perception of others). Subjects performed a social task (purchasing for others), implicating empathy and social cognition. Not a review; likely healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study presenting observation of non-painful touch to others, investigating vicarious somatosensory activation linked to empathy (social perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original research article, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports human fMRI during live eye contact (dyadic social interaction), a social processing task; not a review. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy criteria.

fMRI study of charitable donation decisions—a social decision-making task engaging social-cognition regions. Not a review; likely healthy adult participants. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Abstract provides only title/metadata and does not state whether fMRI was task-based or resting-state, nor whether a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65) was included. Title implies ASD and social-cognition networks, but information is insufficient to determine eligibility—include for full-text review.

Study used fMRI during a social-feedback risk task with healthy participants. However, sample age is 8–17 (adolescents); abstract does not clarify whether there are participants ≥17 or a distinct adult group. Insufficient age detail to rule out inclusion, so include for full-text review to confirm age-range eligibility.

Abstract reports multivoxel pattern analysis of affective touch processing in autism, implying an fMRI social-processing task comparing groups. No abstract text explicitly confirms presence of healthy adult control group or ages; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI methods and presence of healthy participants aged 17–65.

Study uses functional MRI with a social-related task (viewing social scenes/mentalizing) and links dmPFC response to daily social behavior in human participants. Abstract indicates primary data (not a review) and targets social cognition; likely healthy adult sample. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing. Included for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study of social evaluation (impression formation) in healthy young and older adults; directly addresses social processing. Not a review. Ages not explicitly listed but young group likely within 17–65, so include for full-text review to confirm age ranges.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed a social-related task (facial emotion recognition), directly addressing social perception/communication. At least one group is healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm; no evidence participants performed a social-related task. Additionally, intraoperative cortical stimulation implies a patient/surgical population rather than healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining processing of direct vs. averted gaze (a social cue). Includes a typically developing healthy comparison group. Abstract confirms social-related task and human participants. Age range not specified (adolescents and adults), so full text should be checked for healthy group ages (17–65). Include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

fMRI study of empathy (observation of others' pain), which is social cognition (Perception/Understanding of Others). Study includes healthy control participants. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, it meets inclusion criteria pending age confirmation in full text.

Abstract describes a review/methods discussion of hyperscanning techniques (EEG, fMRI, fNIRS) and recommends future EEG-fMRI work; it does not report an original fMRI experiment, participants, or a social task in healthy adults. Not an empirical fMRI study of social processing.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a body-perception task comparing own vs other bodies — fits social-related constructs (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). Sample comprises healthy adults (15M,15F). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

Functional MRI was used while healthy adult participants reflected on self and their mother (social cognition: perception/understanding of self/others). Participants are healthy adults; task is social-related. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review article (overview of the field), not an original fMRI study. The abstract describes prior fMRI and lesion findings rather than reporting new functional MRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Participants are adolescents (ASD and typically developing controls aged 12–18). No healthy adult group within the required age range (17–65) is reported, so the study does not meet the inclusion criterion.
Participants are infants aged 4–7 months, not healthy adults (17–65); thus the study does not meet the age/participant inclusion criterion for the review.

This article is a review of neuroimaging and imaging genetics studies (a review/meta-analysis), not an original fMRI study with participants performing a social task; exclusion criterion excludes systematic reviews/meta-analyses.
This article is a systematic review of fMRI and DTI studies in ASD (not an original fMRI study of healthy adults). The exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' is clearly met.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies. Exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses should be excluded despite relevance to social communication.

This paper is a systematic review (not an original fMRI study). The exclusion criterion ‘systematic reviews or meta-analyses’ is met, so it should be excluded. It does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adults.

Functional MRI was performed during a social task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) and the study includes a group of healthy control participants (n=20), indicating fMRI of social processing in adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports a neuroimaging study investigating EBA response to goal-directed actions/intention of others (social cognition). It likely involves fMRI and healthy adults, but the abstract lacks explicit methods/participant details, so include for full-text review.

Single-case fMRI of an 8-year-old with severe neurological damage; participants are not healthy adults (not in 17–65 range) and study does not report task-based social processing in healthy adults. Exclude based on population/age and relevance.

Abstract investigates neural processes underlying perception and production of prosody and correlations with empathy—fits social communication domain. Although methods and participant details not explicitly stated, topic strongly suggests fMRI in healthy adults; insufficient info to exclude, so include for full-text review.

Primary research using fMRI to study impression formation (social perception of others) in participants who appear to be healthy adults; directly assesses social-related processing with functional MRI. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of maternal neural responses to child affect (a social/attachment paradigm) but does not specify participant groups or whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient detail — include for full-text review.

Functional MRI measured during a naturalistic social task (watching a sitcom with quantified social awkwardness). Study includes a healthy control group alongside ASD participants (likely within adult age range). Focuses on social perception/mentalizing, not a review — meets inclusion criteria.

This article is a systematic review of neuroimaging studies in patients with mood disorders rather than a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' and does not clearly report fMRI data from healthy adults in the abstract.

This is a tutorial/methods paper on intersubject correlation; the abstract describes methodological development and best practices and does not report original fMRI data or participant groups. It is not a primary empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports intranasal oxytocin modulating human amygdala reactivity but does not specify whether fMRI was performed during a social-related task or participant health/age. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing; although healthy controls were included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the review criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (cooperation vs. competition) in human participants performing a social task. Appears to involve healthy adults and directly addresses perception/understanding of others; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Abstract describes dyadic fMRI during eye-contact social interaction, a social-related task. It does not specify participant health status or ages 17–65. Because the abstract lacks participant details but meets the review objective, include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

The study used fMRI during passive viewing of natural movies and reports voxel responses to ‘social communication’ content. However, the abstract does not state an explicit social-related task nor participant ages/health. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria — include for full-text review.

The study investigates multimodal neuroimaging correlates of cognitive deficits in schizophrenia using the MCCB, not fMRI during a social-related task. The abstract does not mention social processing or a social task, nor clear inclusion of a healthy adult social-processing group. Therefore it does not meet the review objective.

The abstract describes a narrative review of MRI findings and discusses literature on adolescent brain maturation and social cognition; it does not report original fMRI data on healthy adult participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This article is a literature review of motor lateralization in autism, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It is a review/meta-analytic type paper (explicitly reviews the literature), meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Task is an interpersonal pleasant touch fMRI paradigm assessing social reward/contextual social processing. Study includes a matched healthy control group of non-using adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets criteria for fMRI social-related task and contains healthy participants aged within adult range.

Abstract reports neural correlates of mentalizing but does not specify that a task-based functional MRI was conducted, nor participant ages or health status. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task and sample (healthy adults 17–65).

Abstract discusses social cognition/emotional intelligence but does not specify a task-based fMRI or whether healthy adult participants (17–65) were included. Insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria—include for full-text review to determine imaging modality, task, and participant groups.

fMRI study where participants performed social-related tasks (attending to meaning of symbolic artifacts; self vs others), reporting activations in social cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus). Not a review; appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in fMRI. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health details.

fMRI task involves social evaluations (self, friend, perspective-taking) and includes a healthy comparison group. However, participants are described as adolescents with no ages reported; eligibility requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Age information is insufficient from the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria.

fMRI was used during perception of emotional gestures (social processing) and the study includes both autism and control groups (healthy participants). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are adults (17–65).

Primary fMRI study in healthy adults performing a social task (intergroup competition) measuring self-referential mPFC responses and willingness to harm competitors. No clinical groups or review/meta-analysis; fits inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult volunteers performing social-related tasks (empathic and forgivability judgments). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI was used while participants played charades (a social communication task) measuring mirroring and mentalizing between healthy participants. The study examines social processing in adults and is an original empirical fMRI paper.

Study examines pediatric populations (youth at familial risk and patients with bipolar disorder) and does not report on healthy adult participants (age 17–65) or on social-related fMRI tasks in adults. Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 12 healthy adult volunteers performing a self-face vs familiar/unfamiliar face recognition task—fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ social processing. Participants are healthy and within adult age range; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.

fMRI was recorded while participants (presumably healthy adults) recalled World War II displays — a task examining collective memory and social-cognitive schema in the medial prefrontal cortex. This is social-related processing (social cognition/collective memory) in humans and fits the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study assessing recognition of others' action 'vitality forms' (perception/understanding of others), participants viewed videos and performed social-related tasks (how vs what). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is primary research (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study used a social threat reactivity task (socially threatening images), addressing social-related processing. Includes a healthy control group of age- and ethnicity-matched women (presumably adults). Abstract does not specify exact ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65, but otherwise meets inclusion criteria.

This is an animal (monkey) study using fMRI with electrical microstimulation of primate inferotemporal cortex; subjects are not human adults and no human social-task fMRI was performed. Does not meet inclusion criterion of fMRI in healthy human participants (age 17–65).

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (18 male non-musicians) reporting activation of ToM/social-cognition areas (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) during aesthetic appreciation.
