Abstract describes a clinical sample of 14 females with BPD/ACE focus and does not report any group of healthy adults (age 17–65). Although it uses emotional processing, no healthy control group is indicated, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group.

The study used fMRI during facial emotion processing, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy control group (normal users) within an adult sample and thus meets inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (e.g., review article) apply based on the abstract.

Event-related fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants investigating social context and perceived agency on empathy for others' pain — a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in 40 healthy volunteers viewing masked and unmasked emotional faces — a social-related task (perception of others' emotions/affiliation). Participants described as healthy adults, fits age range; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

This is a review article summarizing studies of social cognition in bipolar disorder, not an original fMRI study of human participants performing a social task. Excluded per the criterion excluding systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study comparing neural responses to familiar vs unfamiliar faces (social perception of others). Includes an age-matched healthy control group alongside a patient, meeting the criterion of at least one healthy participant group. Not a review/meta-analysis.

This study is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (not an original fMRI experiment). Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews or meta-analyses are excluded. fMRI study of face perception and spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge—clearly social cognitive processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults; age/health not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

Event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments tied to self-referential processing/theory-of-mind (social cognition). Abstract clearly reports relevant task and healthy participants, so include for full-text review.

Study uses fMRI to examine deception (a social-processing task), but abstract does not specify presence of a healthy adult group or participant ages. Insufficient information to determine inclusion—include for full-text review to confirm participants and task details.

Study uses MRI for ASD vs control classification (ABIDE I); abstract describes functional connectivity and structural features but does not report a task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults (likely resting-state). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a review/introduction to a special issue (review of mirror neuron findings), not an original fMRI study. The abstract contains no methods or data from an fMRI task in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study using a face emotional processing task directly addresses social perception/understanding. The abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI was performed during a facial imitate/observe task (a social-processing paradigm) and the sample includes people with and without severe mental illness, indicating healthy controls are present. Age range not reported in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm ages.

The study reports longitudinal fMRI in early adolescents (developmental sample) examining the action observation network; the abstract does not describe any healthy adult (age 17–65) participant group. Thus it fails the age-group inclusion criterion.

fMRI was performed while participants completed a scanner-adapted Multifaceted Empathy Test (a social cognition/empathy task). Functional MRI was used while healthy adult participants (n=20) received empathic vs. unempathic social responses after negative performance feedback, directly probing social processing/empathy. fMRI study using a social-emotional simulation task (imagining another’s pain), includes a psychiatrically-healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Human fMRI study investigating perception and production of facial expressions and social hand gestures (social communication). Involves healthy participants performing a social-related task and is an original empirical study (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in adults.

This is a methodological/neuroscience review of magnetoencephalography (MEG), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. fMRI study of social perception (faces/people vs scenes/objects) that includes a healthy adult comparison group (n=14). Task is social-related and participants are human adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining neural responses to witnessing an emergency (bystander effect), which is a social-related process (perception/understanding of others and action preparation). fMRI study with healthy 'normal volunteers' performing social-related tasks (emotion identification and causal attribution), addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other methodological details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study investigating honesty-related signals and their influence on trust (social cognition/perception of others), fitting the review topic. This is a narrative review of the neurobiology of social phobia, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social task. It meets the exclusion criterion (review), so exclude.

Abstract provides insufficient information to confirm a social-task fMRI in healthy adults. Title suggests adults with autism and connectivity (possibly resting-state) and does not state a healthy control group or task-based social processing. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Participants are early adolescent girls (adolescence), which falls below the required adult age range (17–65). Although the study uses fMRI and a social task, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.
Participants are adolescents aged 11.1–15.5 years with no adult sample within the 17–65 range required by inclusion criteria, so the study fails the age eligibility criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where healthy adult participants made social judgments about people (categorical age estimates and individuating food-preference judgments). The task clearly probes social cognition/perception of others; sample appears to be healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

Two fMRI experiments investigating mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition) in human participants; examines neural representations of others' beliefs—a social-related task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not specified in the abstract, the study clearly meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Original fMRI study investigating neural responses in the extrastriate body area to images of one’s own versus others’ body parts, addressing self/other perception (social cognition). Involves healthy adult participants and a social-related task (perception/understanding of self and others). Not a review. Sufficiently meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed impression-formation about other people (a social-cognitive task). The study examines perception/understanding of others, involves human participants (healthy adult sample implied), and is an original fMRI experiment—not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating Theory of Mind/social cognition using a naturalistic video task (MASC). It clearly addresses social processing; not a review. Abstract does not report participant demographics or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so include for full-text to confirm participants meet age/health criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of emotional prosody (a social communication process) comparing individuals with ASD to control participants, indicating inclusion of healthy controls. Age range not specified in the abstract, so full text is required to confirm participants fall within 17–65. Include for full-text review to verify ages and additional methodological details.

Original fMRI study assessing social brain function during social decisions from faces (affective judgments). Includes healthy adult participants alongside ASD group; task assesses social cognition/perception. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Participants are children (ASD and typically developing children) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although it uses fMRI during a social face-processing task, the age criterion is not met; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing communicative (social communication) versus descriptive speech tasks; investigates neural correlates of social communication, theory-of-mind and social processing in L2. Abstract does not state whether an fMRI was performed or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included; it focuses on autism and reward but provides insufficient methodological/participant details. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract assesses facial emotion processing (a social cognition task) and includes healthy subjects. While it mentions neurofunctional measures, it does not explicitly state use of fMRI or participant ages. Insufficient detail in the abstract to confirm fMRI and age criteria — include for full-text review to verify imaging modality and age range.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining decisions to share articles and neural activity in self-related, valuation, and perspective-taking regions; task involves social processes (sharing, considering others). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include.

Abstract reports fMRI measurement of amygdala responsiveness during social phobia–related word processing (a social-related task) and includes a matched healthy control group (110 controls) alongside 110 patients; participants are adults. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating implicit personal space (affiliation) with social vs non-social stimuli and reported neural activation; meets the review’s social-processing and fMRI requirements. Participant health/ages aren’t specified in the abstract, so full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants reading narratives that probe protected values—a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others/values). Meets inclusion of fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review. Age implied adult; full-text can confirm ages if needed.

fMRI experiment with healthy human participants examining mirror-system responses during action observation/execution after sensorimotor training—addresses perception/understanding of others (action understanding), fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review.

This is a conceptual/primer paper about brain-imaging principles, not an empirical fMRI study. The abstract describes theory and recommendations, with no fMRI methods, tasks, or healthy adult participant data—thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

This article is a review summarizing MRI (including fMRI) findings in autism rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study on healthy adult practitioners using Compassion-meditation and Reappraisal while viewing people in distress; addresses social processing (affiliation/understanding others) and reports neural responses. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social decision-making (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) examining neural correlates of cooperation/defection and social cognition regions in human participants. Abstract does not indicate a clinical sample; task is clearly social. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Participants were two young children with autism spectrum disorder (not healthy adults). Although fMRI during social stimuli was used, the study does not include a healthy adult (age 17–65) group required for inclusion in this review.

Functional MRI study measuring neural responses to biological vs scrambled motion (social perception/social communication) in human participants; task is social-related and aligns with review objective. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract implies healthy adult sample; full-text can confirm ages if needed.

fMRI study in healthy human participants examining perception of affective vocalisations (social communication/perception of others). Abstract indicates task-related fMRI and neural responses in superior temporal sulcus. Participant age/health not specified; include for full-text review to confirm age range/health status.

fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants performing a social communication task (feeling addressed); examines neural processing of body orientation and gesture. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining social attributions (perception/understanding of others) in human participants and reports neural correlates; not a review. Abstract does not specify ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

The study used fMRI during a social (Cyberball) task and includes a healthy control group. However, participants are described as adolescents and ages are not reported, so it is unclear whether healthy subjects meet the 17–65 age criterion—include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study using the ultimatum game (social decision-making), targeting neural networks involved in social interaction. Participant ages are not specified and the study examines developmental changes, so eligibility (age 17–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to determine participant characteristics and confirm inclusion criteria.

Study reports fMRI in 23 healthy adult participants performing a visually-based social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces), directly addressing social processing. Participants are healthy adults and the paper is an original fMRI study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

fMRI BOLD responses were measured while healthy adults (n=35) engaged with idiographic negative self-beliefs and used reappraisal/acceptance. The task targets perception/understanding of self, a social-related construct. Participants are healthy and within the adult age range. Not a review article.

fMRI study examining person perception and mentalising—social cognition processes—in humans. Abstract describes an experimental fMRI task linking perceptual and inferential social networks. It likely tested healthy adult participants, but demographics are not specified; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study of valenced self-referential processing (social-related construct: perception/understanding of self) conducted in 20 adult women. Abstract does not report patient groups or age range or explicit health status, so insufficient to rule out inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults and age 17–65.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task was performed), so it does not meet the inclusion requirement of an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Therefore it should be excluded.

Abstract is a narrative overview that mentions early fMRI studies of social emotions but gives no methods, participant details, or results. Insufficient information to determine whether it reports primary fMRI data on healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This is an editorial/introduction to a special issue, not an original empirical fMRI study. The abstract does not report participants, an fMRI task, or fMRI results; it is a commentary/review of methods. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion of an fMRI scan conducted during a social-related task in human participants.

fMRI study using emotional face/voice classification—a social perception/communication task relevant to social cognition. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so eligibility cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing, all participants (including healthy controls) are children aged 7–13. The review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65, so the study does not meet the age criterion.

Primary fMRI study examining neural responses to social expectancy violations (perception/understanding of others). Uses human participants in a social task; not a review. Likely healthy adult sample. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining self- and other-referential recollection (social cognitive processing) in human participants; reports neural activations (mPFC) during social self/other tasks. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating perception of social cues (fearful gaze) — a social-processing task — and includes a matched healthy adult control group (26 adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

This is a structural MRI study (manual volumetric tracing of fusiform gyrus) in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome and controls. No fMRI data or task-based social processing paradigm is reported; thus it does not meet the inclusion requirement of an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Participants are children (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review. Although a TD group is present, the age range falls outside the inclusion criterion, so the study is not eligible.

This appears to be a review article (published in 'Sexual Medicine Reviews') summarizing fMRI studies of female sexual desire/HSDD rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment. It does not describe a social-related task or primary data in healthy adults. Therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Original fMRI study with healthy participants investigating social cognition (third-party punishment, mentalizing, evaluation of others’ responsibility), meeting the review’s social-related task criterion; not a review or meta-analysis.

Study uses fMRI to examine facial emotion processing (a social cognition task). Abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion/exclusion, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adult participants and relevant task details.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social exchange processing, which matches the review objective of social-related neural processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status; include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criteria.

This is a narrative review of mirror neuron dysfunction in ASD, not an original fMRI study. The abstract reports synthesis of fMRI/TMS/EEG evidence and interventions, with no methods or participant details and no healthy adult fMRI task group; it fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining attentional orienting to social gaze and arrow cues (social communication/perception of others). Appears to use healthy adult participants; no indication it is a review. Abstract lacks explicit age range, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Abstract describes an fMRI randomized controlled study in bipolar disorder patients and reports effects on recognition of happy faces, but does not mention inclusion of any healthy control group. Inclusion criterion requires at least one healthy participant group. Information is insufficient from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of dietary and altruistic (prosocial) choice, with neural decoding of prosocial attributes—this meets the social-related processing domain. The abstract does not specify participant age or health status, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

The study reports fMRI data collected in a chronic traumatic brain injury population and the abstract does not mention any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in human subjects observing an expert demonstrator, investigating motor resonance and mentalizing (perception and understanding of others). Involves healthy adult participant groups (Naïve, Trained, Expert) and social-cognitive processing; not a review.

Participants are adolescent girls tracked from 2nd–8th grades (i.e., below the 17–65 adult range required). Also the task is a risk-taking task rather than a clearly social-processing task. Excluded based on age criterion.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI including explicit 'social' (and emotion) processing in a large Human Connectome Project sample (n=787) of healthy participants. This meets the review’s requirement for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact age range and task details.

fMRI study in 30 healthy participants examining gaze (direct vs averted) effects on action control—a social signal processing task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not stated in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing communicative (social communication) and descriptive speech tasks; examines neural correlates of L2 communication, theory-of-mind and action simulation—clearly a social-related processing task in healthy adults.

fMRI study reporting neural engagement of person-perception and mentalizing networks during tasks manipulating perceived human animacy (social perception). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used during a social interaction task (virtual ball-tossing measuring inclusion/exclusion). The study includes a healthy control group of adults alongside BPD patients, meeting the criterion of at least one healthy participant group. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Functional MRI was used with healthy adult participants (male and female) to investigate perception of interpersonal spatial relations (facing vs nonfacing bodies), a social-related processing task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used to measure brain responses to socially relevant auditory stimuli (one vs two people walking), implicating social-affective and interaction-related regions. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review.

Empirical fMRI study examining mental state decoding ('Reading the Mind in the Eyes')—a social cognition task—in healthy adult participants (native Japanese and white American). Reports neural correlates; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI hemodynamic responses to child stimuli in neural regions associated with social cognition (social processing). Participant health status not specified; insufficient information to confirm healthy adult group, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The article is an overview/narrative review of molecular neuroimaging studies rather than an original fMRI investigation of social tasks in healthy adults. It thus meets the exclusion criterion for review articles and does not report primary fMRI data for inclusion.

fMRI was performed while participants engaged in a social approval task (social reward processing). The study includes a healthy control group (15 adults) alongside a schizophrenia group. It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI performed during speech repetition could relate to social communication, but abstract does not clearly describe a social-related task or social stimuli. Includes healthy participants. Insufficient information to determine social processing—include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study examining mirror-system responses to action sounds and semantic processing—addresses perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages, so inclusion requires full-text to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI 'empathy for pain' task assesses social/affective processing (empathic responses). Study includes both autistic and control (healthy) participants, presumably adult sample, and is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are patients with mild TBI and cognitive impairment; no healthy adult group is reported. The task (playing piano/music rehabilitation) is not a social-processing task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a review article ('We review...') summarizing fMRI findings from human and macaque infants and proposing mechanisms; it is not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclude per exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (implicit from journal/context) investigating memory for neutral faces in goal-relevant vs goal-irrelevant situations; task involves social stimuli (face identity recognition) and reports activation in social-processing region (superior temporal sulcus), matching social-related processing constructs.

This is a theoretical/review paper discussing explanations of mirror-touch synesthesia and referring to fMRI evidence, but it does not report an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social-related task. Not a primary empirical fMRI study meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neural correlates of perceiving social interactions in the human brain (pSTS), indicating an fMRI study of social perception in humans. It addresses social-related processing in healthy adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Include for full-text review to extract details (ages, sample).

fMRI study examining gaze-direction effects on face processing (social perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so eligibility cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult (17–65) sample.

Although the study used fMRI on a moral/social task, all participants were children (one HFA, one Asperger’s, three normal children). The review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65; no healthy adult participants are present.

This study used structural MRI covariance analysis rather than task-based functional MRI (fMRI). It does not report fMRI during social-related tasks, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI scanning during a social task.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of prosodic (social communication) processing in autism but does not specify participant groups or ages. Unable to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) group from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) directly involving social-related processing and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm that healthy participants fall within 17–65 and to extract details.

fMRI study of social cognition (eye gaze, face processing) that includes neurotypical control group. Abstract lacks participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and extract data.

Abstract reports two independent fMRI experiments in humans assessing emotional egocentricity bias (social cognition/empathy). Healthy adult participants are implied; task is social-related. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract states this article summarizes psychopharmacological and fMRI research (a review), not reporting original fMRI data from a human participant sample. This meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (and reviews); insufficient primary fMRI study information for inclusion.

Abstract discusses brain imaging of ToM and empathy in schizophrenia but does not state whether fMRI was conducted during social tasks or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring neural activation during a social cognition task (judging trustworthiness of faces) and includes a healthy control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not stated in the abstract, the sample appears to be adult; meets inclusion criteria for full data extraction.

fMRI study probing social cognition (action observation/execution, action understanding, theory of mind) that included a healthy control group (n=18). Abstract meets criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact ages (17–65) if needed.

fMRI study where participants viewed and recognized actions, probing neural representations in pSTS/MT/MST/EBA—directly relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others. Empirical study with presumed healthy adults; age/health details not reported, so include for full-text review.

The study investigates executive dysfunction and control-network hub modulation in autism, not social-related processing. Although it may include healthy controls, the task is executive, not social; does not meet the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI and correlated Theory of Mind scores with connectivity; no task-based social processing was performed during the scan. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task, so it does not meet the criterion despite having healthy controls.

fMRI study of audiovisual speech integration (social communication/perception), includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group, and involves task-based fMRI in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural representations of others' mental states (social cognition) in male and female human participants; uses social-brain network measures (mPFC, precuneus). Study involves healthy adult participants and is original research (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

The study used simultaneous fMRI (with PET) to probe mothers’ neural responses to their infants—an affiliation/attachment social task—in a sample of adult mothers (healthy adults). It directly examines social bonding/neural processing and is an original human fMRI study, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an original dyadic fMRI (dfMRI) experiment examining face-to-face social interaction and BOLD responses, identifying empathy/mentalization/default-mode networks—meets fMRI social-processing criterion. Not a review. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social exclusion (social interaction/mentalizing) in healthy participants; not a review. Age described as "male adolescents" but exact ages not provided, so include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65.

Study reports task-based fMRI in 22 healthy adult males (within 17–65 range) performing social-related judgments (allocentric social hierarchies, social alliance), directly addressing social processing in healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full review.

Abstract describes fMRI of self- and other-reflection (a social-processing task) but focuses on schizophrenia; it does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information in abstract to confirm inclusion, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants.

Abstract describes a field overview/commentary on social neuroscience rather than an original empirical fMRI study. It provides no methods, participant sample, or task-based fMRI data and thus meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Participants are described as 'youth' (child/adolescent) and study published in a child psychology journal; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported, so it fails the age-based inclusion criterion for the review.

Abstract describes coherence spectral-density analysis of cerebral activity recorded simultaneously in pairs (likely electrophysiological measures such as MEG/EEG) and makes no mention of functional MRI. Does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social-processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls and behavioral social cognition measures are present, the imaging does not meet the task-based criterion.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social interaction task (reaction-time competition with opponents involving provocation and punishment). The paradigm probes social processing (reactive aggression, social decision-making) in humans; no clinical population is reported. Fits inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study in young children (ages 3–7) including an ASD group and matched controls; not a task-based social-processing fMRI study and does not include healthy adult participants (17–65).

Primary research using fMRI during a charitable-giving task probing social processes (empathy, perspective taking, attention). Involves healthy adult participants and directly assesses social cognition; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining affective creativity via reappraisal of anger-evoking events. Authors report recruitment of DMN/social-cognition regions, suggesting involvement of social-related processing. Abstract lacks explicit detail that task probes social interaction, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study examines memory control and functional connectivity during a recognition task, not social-related processing. Although it uses fMRI in healthy adults, the task does not involve social constructs (affiliation, communication, self/other perception). Not a review article.

fMRI was performed showing activation (right middle frontal cortex) while participants evaluated 'self' vs 'non-self' MHC peptides in body odour—a social-related task involving perception/understanding of self and mate-evaluation in healthy volunteers. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining perception of emotions and interactions in dynamic crowds—clearly a social-processing task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant demographics/health, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

The article is explicitly a review summarizing the authors' research program rather than a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite relevance to social perception.

This is a narrative/review of ecstatic and related epileptic phenomena using neuroimaging; it does not report an fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task. Appears to focus on patient cases, not primary fMRI social-processing data.

fMRI study where participants watched dynamic faces and attended to facial aspects (emotional valence, age), addressing perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants; abstract does not state age range but meets the social-processing fMRI criterion. Not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
Participants are children (mean age ~10.1 years), which falls outside the required age range of 17–65 for inclusion. Study otherwise uses fMRI and social tasks but fails the age criterion.

fMRI study with human participants performing a social task (judgments of faces after cooperative/defective play in a Prisoner’s Dilemma), investigates social cognition (moral status, fairness). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages aren’t specified, typical Neuron study implies healthy adult participants; abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI study in a sample of Major Depressive Disorder patients (no healthy control group reported) and no task-based social processing paradigm. Does not meet inclusion criteria requiring task-based fMRI involving social processing and at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

fMRI study using the Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social interaction task) measuring neural responses to cooperation/non-cooperation in healthy adult men and women. Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI in healthy adults) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports original fMRI research (mega-analysis of four fMRI studies) in which participants considered others' mental states — a social cognition task. It therefore meets the requirement of fMRI during social-related processing in (presumably) healthy adult participants. Not a systematic review/meta-analysis.

Study used functional MRI while participants observed human and robot agents experiencing pain/pleasure (an empathy/social cognition task). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=26). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Primary fMRI study using a social ‘social-norm inference’ audio-visual task assessing judgments about others’ reactions. Includes a healthy control group (typical development adults) alongside HFA participants. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets the social-processing and fMRI inclusion criteria.

fMRI experiment (N=31) examined neural responses to disfigured faces, which tests social perception/understanding of others and social cognition (empathy). The study appears to involve healthy adults but the abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study used resting-state/structural MRI (no task-based social fMRI) and participants are boys with mean ages ~11–12 (age ranges 5.5–19.7), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Fails task requirement and age criterion.

fMRI study with congenitally blind and sighted participants performing identity and emotion recognition from voices—clearly social perception (perception of others). Includes healthy participants and is not a review. Abstract lacks explicit ages, so full text may be checked, but sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy non-clinical sample of young adult males (age within 17–65) performing social-related tasks (empathic processing of social interaction scenarios). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

The article is explicitly a review ('In this review...') rather than an original fMRI study. Exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews or meta-analyses; abstract provides no primary fMRI data on healthy adults performing social tasks.

fMRI was conducted during an emotional task and the study includes a healthy control group (n=25, likely adults). The abstract does not clearly state whether the task is explicitly social-related, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm relevance to social processing.

The study reports event-related fMRI collected while participants performed a mind-perception task (social-cognitive processing) and links neural activity to social attention performance. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting the review inclusion criteria.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (no task); inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Abstract does not describe participants performing any social task, so it should be excluded.

Abstract reports an fMRI study with pupillometry examining pupil-mimicry effects on trust and recruitment of theory-of-mind network—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Study appears to involve human participants (likely healthy adults) and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Sufficient information to include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study using social scenarios examining emotional responses to risky decisions; includes healthy young adult participants (young adults and late adolescents) performing a social-related task. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

Block-design fMRI study of perception of facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), measuring neural responses in face-selective regions. This fits the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study used BOLD fMRI (3T) during processing of humorous cartoons, framed as social cognition, in 29 healthy subjects. This fits the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age range not reported—include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Study is an RCT protocol for a behavioral intervention in individuals with psychotic disorder; abstract contains no fMRI methods or social-task neuroimaging and does not focus on healthy adult participants.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants retrieved biographical/person knowledge (social processing). The task involves perception/understanding of others (social knowledge retrieval). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Participants were recruited while entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety; the abstract does not report any healthy adult comparison group. Thus it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

Event-related fMRI study in humans investigating processing of angry voice prosody (social communication/social cognition). Participants performed a social-related task (attending to voices); likely healthy adult sample; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

Functional MRI study of social communication (communicative intentions). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65). Insufficient detail to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (learning to simulate others’ decisions) using behavioral, modeling, and fMRI methods. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

Task-based fMRI investigating interpersonal trust/distrust (social-attitude control) in healthy adult participants (n=60). Study targets social cognition/perception of others and reports neural activity during task; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) performed during task-based scanning; includes a healthy adult control group (25 age- and gender-matched controls). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy participants 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study reports resting-state functional connectivity in cocaine-dependent individuals and examines delay discounting and reversal learning (cognitive control), not social-related processing. It does not describe a social task or a healthy adult group performing social processing during fMRI.

Abstract reports fMRI during social-distance trials (photographs of participants' friends vs acquaintances), indicating a social-processing task in humans. Not a review. Participant health and ages not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of gesture-speech integration (social communication) including healthy adult control groups (n=19, n=17). Task involves social-related processing and is not a review. Although ages not specified, participants are described as adult healthy controls; sufficient for inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study using the Trust Game (social decision-making) examining neural correlates of Machiavellian traits. This addresses social-related processing in an apparent healthy adult sample; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion; full text can confirm ages and health if needed.

Primary fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing social-related task (implicit/explicit emotional facial expression processing—social communication/perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a Theory of Mind (social) task relevant to social processing. Includes a matched control group of presumably healthy participants alongside high-risk relatives. Abstract is not explicit about participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm demographics and details.

Study used event-related fMRI (with simultaneous EEG) in 14 healthy adults (mean age 29±6) while they viewed and evaluated others' emotional facial expressions—an explicit social processing task (perception/understanding of others/empathy). Participants are within the 17–65 age range and this is an original empirical study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of observation and mental imagery of face and limb movements addressing limb gesture processing and social communication—fits social-processing domain. Abstract does not state participant demographics/ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Study uses fMRI to measure neural responses to viewing/listening to another person’s non-verbal facial and vocal behaviors—fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages; because inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group and this is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to verify sample eligibility.

Functional MRI was used while participants processed emotional facial expressions (a social-related task). The study includes a healthy control group (mean age 27, within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study examining how learning another person's values alters value representations in mPFC and behavior—clearly a social-learning task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy adult human participants (typical for this journal), though ages/health not explicitly stated; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

fMRI study examining social communication/vitality forms in speech and actions; tasks require processing social aspects (speech prosody, action expression). Human participants (adult participants implied) scanned with fMRI. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study reports task-based fMRI analysis including a social cognition task (explicitly listed among task domains). Abstract indicates whole-brain task-modulated connectivity during tasks, meeting the review objective of social-related processing. Participant details (healthy adult status and ages 17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm sample criteria.

fMRI study examining direct and reflected self-appraisals (social-related processing). Includes a healthy adult group aged 23–30 (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study includes a theory-of-mind (social attribution of belief) task probing social cognition. Participants scanned with fMRI; likely healthy adults though ages not specified in abstract. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study investigating implicit false-belief (theory of mind) processing—clearly a social-cognitive task involving perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages, but likely healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

Study used fMRI during a social exclusion (interactive ball-toss) task probing social processing in humans; reports neural responses and individual differences. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-task in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

Original fMRI study in healthy adult humans examining effort production during collaborative vs competitive (social) contexts; addresses social cognition/motivation and uses functional MRI. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

The article is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation of 125 fMRI studies), and thus meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses.' The abstract indicates no new primary participant data. Exclude based on abstract alone.

fMRI performed in healthy adult women (ages 25–50) during viewing of erotic pictures/videos, which taps perception of others and sexual/affiliative responses (social-affective processing). Meets inclusion (social-related task in healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text review.
This article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with human participants; excluded per the exclusion criterion.
This is a resting-state fMRI parcellation study, not a task-based fMRI of social processing. No social-related task or measures are reported in the abstract, so it is irrelevant.

Functional MRI was performed during an explicit emotion-recognition task (social perception/understanding of others) in a sample of healthy young adult males (within 17–65). The study examines neural responses (amygdala) to social/emotional stimuli and is not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social appraisal task (liking emotional faces) with a healthy control group (n=21) and patient group. Task targets social processing/perception of others. Not a review. Abstract doesn’t state exact ages but participants are adults; meets inclusion—include for full-text review if age needs confirmation.

fMRI study of abstract vs concrete mindsets framed within social cognition. Participants performed why/how and category/exemplar tasks, but abstract does not clearly state use of explicit social stimuli or social-processing tasks. Information is insufficient to determine exclusion, so include for full-text review to confirm applicability to social-related processing.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment investigating social-cognitive processes (imitation control, self–other distinction, mental state attribution), matching the review’s social-related processing objective. It is not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

Abstract reports human participants performing cooperative/competitive tasks with neural tracking in frontal regions (area 9, ACC), indicating fMRI measurement of social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met and sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Original fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants viewing social-evaluative videos (social communication/perception of others). Task clearly assesses social-related processing; participants are healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review and data extraction.

fMRI hyperscanning study of mutual gaze and joint attention—clearly social-processing tasks. Involves human participant pairs (presumably healthy adults) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Abstract does not contradict inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status if needed.

This is a review article summarizing neuroimaging literature on face processing in ASD, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract describes no original fMRI methods, participants, or data from healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan conducted with human participants performing a social-related task.

Study reports an fMRI experiment where participants attributed awareness to a cartoon face (a social attribution task related to perception/understanding of others). It involves healthy human subjects and is not a review. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (17–65) if needed.

fMRI study in adult mothers exposing them to infant cries (social/attachment-related task). Participants are human adults (likely healthy mothers) within target age range; task probes affiliation/attachment and social processing. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task during scanning). Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; therefore exclude despite presence of healthy controls.

fMRI task involved active listening to human footsteps and reports engagement of the 'social cognition' posterior STS, indicating social-related processing (perception of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (viewing/assessing social groups; perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria for full-text data extraction.

This is an fMRI study of emotional speech prosody (social communication) in human participants performing explicit and implicit social-related tasks. It reports data from 22 subjects (presumably healthy adults) and is an original research article, not a review. Fits the review objective; include for full-text screening to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study with healthy participants viewing a moral dilemma about kin vs non-kin; investigates social-cognitive processes (moral conflict, mentalizing, decision making) relevant to social relatedness. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy young adults performing tasks that include peer observation and social-cognitive processing (peer influence, social cognition). Participants are within the target age range and healthy; not a review. The abstract indicates social-related processing during task-based fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.
This is a resting-state fMRI connectivity study (no task was performed during scanning). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social-related processing; therefore it does not meet the criterion.

Abstract lacks key details: no explicit mention of fMRI scanning or presence of a healthy control group. The topic (visual personal familiarity) could involve social processing, but information is insufficient to determine eligibility. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant groups.

fMRI was used while participants performed social cognition tasks (reasoning about others’ mental states). Participants are described as neurologically normal (healthy). No exclusion criteria met. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65.

All participants were non-treatment-seeking individuals with alcohol use disorder (n=15); no healthy control group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a review/chapter summarizing amygdala findings across neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders, not an original fMRI experiment. It does not report fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks; therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews.

Functional MRI was used while participants made self- and friend-related social judgments (self/other trait and memory), directly addressing social cognitive processing (self/other). The study reports original fMRI data in healthy participants (adult sample implied) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies; include for full-text review.

This is a conceptual/review article discussing relationships between emotion perception and theory of mind and synthesizing lesion and fMRI findings, not an original fMRI study. The abstract indicates it is a review rather than reporting a functional MRI experiment in healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension (social communication/perception of others). It addresses social processing in adults. Participant details (health/age) are not specified in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adults where participants received interpersonal manual touch by other people (a social-touch paradigm). This probes social-related processing (social interaction/perception of others) during scanning. Participants are healthy adults within the target age range and the study is empirical (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

Study used resting-state fMRI in toddlers with autism and an eye-tracking–identified ASD subtype, not a task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults. Participants are young children with ASD (not healthy 17–65 adults), so it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

fMRI study probing social cognition (responses to emotionally salient human eyes/mentalizing). Abstract indicates comparison between Tourette patients and healthy controls (adults), meeting requirement for a healthy adult group (likely age 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis (combining data from 22 fMRI and 2 PET studies) rather than a primary fMRI study. Exclusion criteria explicitly remove systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite its relevance to social processing.

FMRI study using a social task (Trust Game) investigating social perspective-taking in healthy participants. Abstract does not report participant ages; adolescents likely include minors, so age eligibility (≥17) is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and full eligibility.

This is a review/book chapter discussing developmental social neuroscience and adolescent social influence, not an original fMRI study. The abstract provides no fMRI methods, participant details, or adult (17–65) healthy sample. It therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports changes in brain activation and connectivity linked to compassion training and altruistic responses to others’ suffering in healthy adults, implying an fMRI task probing social cognition/perception of others. Fits inclusion (social-related processing, healthy adult sample) and is not a review.

No functional MRI was conducted; the study reports focus group and questionnaire data from teenage students (adolescents), not an fMRI task in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

The fMRI study investigates nonconscious memory and emotional valence using a recognition memory task with visual stimuli, not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, communication, self/other perception). Although participants are healthy adults, the task does not involve social constructs, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis), not original primary fMRI data. The review's exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI was conducted while human participants performed a social perception task (categorizing actions; involves mentalizing/motor resonance networks). Not a review. Although participant ages/health not specified in abstract, the study likely uses healthy adults; insufficient detail on age/clinical status means include for full-text verification.

The article is a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (activation likelihood estimation). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this study should be excluded.

Study reports fMRI of language/semantic comprehension in patients with schizophrenia; abstract does not describe a social-related task nor mention a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study involves preschool-aged children with autism spectrum disorder, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Abstract does not describe an fMRI social-task in healthy adult participants; therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 21 healthy adult male participants (within 17–65). Task involved perception/understanding of dyadic nonverbal social interactions (social communication/perception of others), meeting the review’s social-related task criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis and no exclusion criteria met based on the abstract.

Healthy adult volunteers underwent fMRI including an experimental task contrasting anticipation of touching an animate (human hand) vs inanimate target—an explicit social-related interaction/perception paradigm. Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI, social processing, healthy participants). Not a review.

Two fMRI experiments examining mentalizing (social cognition) about individuals and groups; task involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages/health not specified, context strongly indicates healthy adult sample; meets inclusion.

Study reports fMRI in healthy adults (trustee role in the Trust Game), a clearly social-related task probing reciprocity/social processing. Participants are healthy adults and this is original research (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (not within the required 17–65 adult range), and the fMRI task examined basic auditory-visual perceptual processing rather than social-related processing; no healthy adult group is present.

fMRI study of perception and understanding of others (processing facial expressions of disgust), a social-cognitive task in humans. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study using the cyberball social inclusion task (social processing) and includes a healthy control group (17 HC). Participants are adults (clinical groups and HCs) and the task probes social inclusion; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

The study investigates hypnotic suggestion-induced modulation of pain and sensory processing, not a social-related task or social cognitive construct. The abstract does not describe social interaction, communication, or perception/understanding of self/others, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI studies.

Abstract reports fMRI in individuals with PAX6 mutation during verbal fluency and sentence completion, but does not clearly describe a social-related task or the presence of a healthy adult control group. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility for a social-processing meta-analysis, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social-related processing (neural responses to outcomes for self, friend, antagonist) in healthy participants. Meets inclusion of social-task fMRI and healthy group. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

The study used repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) to test causal role of right IPL rather than conducting functional MRI during a social task. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan; thus it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining neural and behavioral responses to gaze shifts (social cognition/joint attention) in humans. Abstract indicates a social-related task relevant to social perception. Participant health/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural activity when attributing intentions to human- versus computer-generated music, directly assessing mental state attribution/social cognition (aMFC, STS, temporal poles). Fits inclusion criteria (fMRI, social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review.

Empirical fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (judging social orientation of point-light displays and human-like walkers), probing mirror and mentalizing systems. Fits review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and extract details.

fMRI was performed measuring brain response to fearful faces (a social/emotional processing task) in adult males. The study includes a healthy control group matched for IQ/age/education, meeting the requirement of at least one healthy participant group. Therefore it fits the meta-analysis objective.
Participants are children with autism spectrum disorder; no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included. Does not meet the review’s requirement of at least one healthy adult participant group.

7T fMRI study conducting a rest-task-rest paradigm where participants listened to attachment-related social narratives (attachment/affiliation processing). Includes healthy adult participants (23 healthy males). This directly assesses social-related processing in healthy adults, meeting inclusion criteria and not a review.

Event-related fMRI study investigating perception of gender from faces—a social perception task (understanding others). Abstract does not state participant health or ages; insufficient detail to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy criteria. Include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics and confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining mentalizing, empathy and prosocial behavior (social cognition) in human participants. The task is social-related (mentalizing about similar/dissimilar others) and reports neural activation (dmPFC, vlPFC). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Relevant to the review objective—include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status if needed.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using a social-evaluation task (in-group/out-group politician trait ratings), directly examining social processing and vACC responses. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
Abstract does not specify use of fMRI or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because key inclusion information is missing, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This paper is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (meta-analysis) of fMRI studies, not a primary fMRI study. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Primary fMRI study of social judgment/perception of others (social processing). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy sample; per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm participants meet healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI activation differences (default mode network) during action-sentence processing in healthy adults; the 'why' (abstract) condition may tap social-cognitive processes (understanding reasons/intentions). The abstract does not clearly state social/affiliation/other-specific tasks, so information is insufficient to determine exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm whether task meets social processing criteria.

fMRI study employing a dynamic facial-expression localizer and neurofeedback targeting pSTS; task assesses perception of others’ facial expressions (social processing). Conducted in human subjects (reported across subjects) and is not a review. Although ages not specified in abstract, the study fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and warrants inclusion for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of empathy for pain and prosocial behavior in (presumably) healthy adult participants, addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is an original empirical study, not a review. Sufficient information in the abstract indicates it meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using the Trust Game, a social interaction task probing reciprocity and perspective-taking (perception/understanding of others). No indication participants were clinical; meets inclusion of healthy adult social-processing fMRI. Not a review or meta-analysis. Include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants observing others’ actions; task investigates representation of others’ actions/interactions (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of vocal emotion recognition (social processing). Participants are healthy and aged 8–19, which includes ages 17–19 falling within the 17–65 eligibility window; however, it’s unclear whether there is a distinct adult group. Include for full-text review to confirm age-group eligibility and other details.

Study reports fMRI during participants’ judgments about social categories/stereotypes (a social cognition task). Participants are human and presumably healthy adults; task clearly involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

Abstract describes an fMRI social-cognitive task (visual perspective-taking) in ASD and schizophrenia but does not state whether a healthy control group is included. Insufficient participant detail in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65) and fMRI task details.

This study used structural MRI (cortical thickness and structural covariance) in ASD vs controls rather than task-based functional MRI of social processing in healthy adults. No fMRI social-task in healthy 17–65 participants is described, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study reports resting-state brain activity in bvFTD patients; no task-based fMRI of social processing is described and abstract does not indicate inclusion of a healthy adult task-performing group (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the requirement for task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI in children (ASD and typically developing), not task-based social processing; participants are children, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore does not meet inclusion criteria for task-based social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used during a facial emotion recognition task (a social-processing task) and the study included a neurotypical control group of adults; meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

Original fMRI study investigating neural correlates of social interaction (emotion alignment) while pairs of participants rated and communicated emotional arousal. Tasks are clearly social (social communication/influence). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not explicitly state ages/health, but study context implies healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) performing a social-related task—observation/processing of others’ mouth actions—examining mirror, empathy, and social cognition networks. Fits inclusion criteria (social processing in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study examining neural mechanisms of persuasion/expert influence — a social cognitive process (social influence, trust, evaluation). Abstract reports task-based fMRI linking expert context to brain activity in regions for social valuation and memory. No exclusion criteria met; likely conducted in healthy adults. Recommend full-text inclusion.

Includes an original fMRI experiment comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal (ROI BOLD analyses) in an independent dataset, so it is not solely a meta-analysis. Meets review objective of fMRI studies of social processing. Full text should be checked to confirm participant ages and health, but abstract provides sufficient grounds to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social feedback addressing social-related processing (inclusion/exclusion). Participants described as a ‘population-derived sample of adolescents’ but ages not specified; unclear whether participants fall within the review’s 17–65 range. Abstract otherwise meets inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

The abstract explicitly states this paper is a review of task-related functional neuroimaging studies in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome rather than original fMRI experiments. It is therefore a systematic review-style article and meets the exclusion criterion; no evidence it reports fMRI data from healthy adults.

Abstract is brief and does not state whether a functional MRI task was used or report participant ages/health status. Title suggests neuroimaging of mentalising including typical development and ASD, so it may include healthy adult controls. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and age range—include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy participants judged social concepts (social semantic processing). Task directly probes social-related processing; meets inclusion. Abstract indicates healthy participants and neural correlates in anterior temporal and medial prefrontal cortex. No exclusion criteria met.

Original fMRI study using dynamic audio-visual emotional stimuli addressing perception of others’ emotions (social cognition). Not a review. Although participant ages/health status not explicitly stated in abstract, the paradigm and objectives strongly indicate healthy adult participants; include for full-text confirmation if needed.

fMRI study modeling neural responses to sentences; analysis includes a factor for social interaction vs physical state, indicating social-processing content. Abstract does not specify participant ages but likely healthy adults; insufficient detail on demographics, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports behavioral judgments of ambiguous social interactions following rough/smooth touch and describes associated neural activation (primary/secondary somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, inferior prefrontal cortex), indicating neuroimaging during a social task in healthy adults. The abstract does not explicitly state ‘fMRI’ or participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant demographics.

fMRI study where healthy volunteers performed judgments of a self-conscious social emotion (pride) vs basic positive emotion (joy), engaging social cognition/theory-of-mind processes. Sample described as healthy participants; age range not specified in abstract so include for full-text confirmation. Not a review.

This is a review article of functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) studies in Autism Spectrum Disorder (children/infants), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews and does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not specify that fMRI was used, nor does it report participant ages or that healthy adults (17–65) were included. Although face processing is a social-related construct, the study appears developmental. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from the abstract—include for full-text review.

fMRI study presenting dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset of happy and angry faces) addressing social communication/perception. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant age/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI experiment manipulating social competition (a social interaction/processing task) in human participants, meeting review focus. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults 17–65.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self) in right-handed healthy subjects, matching the review focus on social-related processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study using a socio-emotional preference task examining social preference processing and network interactions, directly addressing social-related processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to verify participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI study in which participants (31 healthy controls) performed an agency inference task addressing perception/understanding of self (agency), a social-related construct.
