Although clinical groups are the main focus, healthy control whole-brain task effects are presented and comparisons to controls are described. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social-task whole-brain data in healthy adults.

Although the study reports whole-brain, group-level fMRI activation maps for the control group (satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion), the sample does not include a healthy adult group within the required age range (17–65). All participant groups are adolescents (ages 12–18, group means ~14–15 years); no separate healthy adult subgroup is reported. Therefore the sample criterion (at least one healthy adult group) is not met. No adult-specific results are provided that could be generalized to healthy adults. Exclude on age/sample grounds.

Although this fMRI study examines social/affiliative processing in healthy adult mothers and reports group-level voxelwise contrasts and coordinates, all statistical inference appears to have been conducted using an ROI approach with small-volume correction (SVC). The authors do not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map or whole-brain-corrected results generalizable to healthy adults; reported effects are restricted to predefined ROIs and SVC-corrected clusters. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for at least one whole-brain, univariate task-evoked map from the healthy adult group.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction (real-time mutual eye contact) conducted in healthy adult participants (final N=30–32; mean age ~21.7, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) using GLM with cluster-level FWE correction and provides cluster details/coordinates and figures. Although additional connectivity and interbrain synchronization analyses are included, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy sample are clearly reported. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of empathy for pain (social perception/understanding of others) using a task with pain vs. no-pain stimuli. The sample includes healthy adult participants including a young group (20–30 years) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation maps/contrasts (pain>no pain and pain>baseline) and age-group contrasts, thresholded and described (FWE-corrected and uncorrected results, tables/figures and neurovault links provided). Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore the manuscript provides whole-brain task-evoked activation evidence from healthy adult participants and meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (TD, ages 18–34) and uses an ecologically valid social fMRI task, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Analyses are ICA-based (GIG-ICA) with component spatial maps and component-level temporal-sorting beta-weights (component-wise effects, and between-group/component beta comparisons). No unmasked whole-brain voxelwise within-group task activation contrast (e.g., TD show>no-show SPM/t-map or coordinate table) is provided. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain univariate task evidence and must be excluded.

While the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants and investigates social interaction (cooperation/competition), it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., standard GLM contrast or coordinate table of task activation). Instead, analyses are data-driven gICA component maps and inter-subject correlation (ISC) coupling measures (multivariate/component-based and connectivity-like metrics). These component spatial maps and ISC coupling coefficients do not satisfy the review's requirement for an univariate, voxelwise healthy-group task activation map. All other inclusion criteria (healthy adults, social task) are met, but failure to provide a whole-brain univariate task effect excludes the paper.

This fMRI study used a task (self-paced reading of a literary narrative with suspense ratings) that evokes social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/theory-of-mind and inference about characters). Participants were healthy adults (N=23; ages 19–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (parametric suspense regressor and reading>rating contrasts) with cluster- and FWE-corrected results and tabulated peak coordinates; whole-brain effects are clearly described. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception/understanding of others via point-light social interactions) in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 29.4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (SI > NSI contrast) using random-effects one-sample t-tests and FDR correction, with activations described across the whole brain (figures/tables and anatomical localization). No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only limitations apply. Participants are within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy adult group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study does not include a healthy adult sample (age 17–65). The participant groups are adolescents (8–18 years), and although a typically developing (TD) control group is reported, it is not an adult subgroup and results are not reported for a separate healthy adult sample. While the study uses whole-brain task fMRI and reports univariate within-group effects for the TD participants on social joint-attention tasks, it fails the sample-age inclusion criterion. Therefore it cannot be included in a meta-analysis targeting healthy adults (17–65).

This is a task-based fMRI study of socio-emotional (empathy/understanding of others) processing using campaign vs. control videos, satisfying the review’s domain. The sample comprises healthy adults (n=20 males, ages 20–28) reported as a control group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise results (CV>NV contrast) thresholded at p<0.05 FWE with cluster peaks/coordinates and figures/tables, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, and the healthy-group task effect is clearly presented. Although the sample is all-male and modest in size, this does not violate inclusion criteria. Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, age mean 20.65) using task-based paradigms probing event simulation, explicit/implicit situational inference, and future prediction. The tasks include social situations (42.7% of stimuli) and the manuscript frames findings in social-cognitive terms (theory of mind, trait inference). Whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses are reported (SPM8 random-effects one-sample t-tests; cluster-corrected and coordinate results reported), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The healthy-group results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range). Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper reports only an ROI analysis of the anterior rostral MPFC and explicitly states that whole-brain and functional connectivity analyses could not be conducted due to signal loss. No group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map (or equivalent voxelwise contrast) for the healthy/control group is presented. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain task-evoked map for the healthy adult group.

This is an fMRI study using a social task (Ultimatum Game – a social exchange paradigm probing fairness, cooperation, and affiliation) in healthy adult participants (n=51; mean ages ~31, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (GLM, conjunction analyses, interaction contrasts) with voxelwise statistical maps and coordinate tables (MNI coordinates; FDR-corrected results reported), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. While the study also reports ROI and PPI analyses, it clearly includes generalizable healthy-group whole-brain activation results (e.g., anterior insula, septal region) suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study with a sample of healthy adult participants (35 volunteers, mean age 29) performing a face identity VSTM task where emotional expressions (angry, happy, neutral) are manipulated. The task clearly probes social processing (perception/understanding of others' emotional expressions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANCOVA; FDR-corrected maps, Talairach coordinates and cluster tables are provided) for emotion and load contrasts derived from the healthy participant group. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain maps are presented and described. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, mean age ~25) that probes social cognition (agency attribution/theory of mind using Heider–Simmel–style animations). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise contrasts (High>Low and Low>High) analyzed with SPM2 and thresholded at p<0.001, and describes activated regions (STS, IFG, occipital cortices, etc.). It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses, includes a healthy adult sample within the 17–65 range, and provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The sample consists entirely of children and adolescents (N=55; age range 8.1–16.5 years, M=13.34). No healthy adult group (age 17–65) or separate adult subgroup analyses are reported. Although the study reports whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI analyses of social processing, it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult participant group. Therefore it must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: The study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (observation of interpersonal touch videos addressing socio-affective processing). (2) Sample: Includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (21 neurotypical adults, ages consistent with adults) with results reported separately from the ASD group. (3) Whole-brain evidence: The manuscript reports group-level univariate whole-brain task effects (mean group effects for social vs. non-social touch contrasts) and refers to whole-brain results and MNI coordinates in the main text and supplementary materials (Additional file, Figure S2 and Table S2). The study is empirical, not ROI-only or resting-state only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and understanding of self and others via a body-perception task). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=30, 15 males, 15 females; mean age 26), within the 17–65 range, with analyses reported separately for healthy controls. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (thresholded Z-statistic group maps, cluster-corrected p-values) for multiple contrasts (own body vs scrambled, same-sex other vs scrambled, opposite-sex other vs scrambled, parametric self-similarity effects), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Whole-brain results are described in text, figures, and supporting tables. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study (n=19 healthy, right-handed adults, ages 18–58) examines prosody perception/production and empathy — a social-communication task relevant to the review. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) analyzed with random-effects models and thresholded at p<0.05 FDR with a minimum cluster size (k>5); results and coordinate lists are provided (including supplementary materials). Healthy adult results are reported separately and are generalizable to the control/healthy population. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses, and includes explicit whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (male, 18–24) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Popular>Notes, Artistic>Notes, Popular>Artistic) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FDR correction. Although the paradigm is aesthetic music appreciation (beauty ratings), the authors explicitly frame and report results in terms of social-cognitive processes (cognitive empathy/ToM and default-mode network engagement) and interpret artistic music as recruiting social cognition/mentalizing regions. Thus the task probes social-related processing broadly (perception/understanding of others/empathic engagement) and satisfies the sample and whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (facial emotion discrimination — perception/understanding of others). The sample includes healthy adult control participants (NC; n=27, ages 19–35) reported separately from the excessive smartphone user group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results: within-group contrasts for the control group and between-group contrasts with clusters and FWE-corrected significance (tables of regions/clusters are described), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. The methods describe standard whole-brain GLM analysis and reporting of cluster-level results (FWE-corrected p-values), and results for the healthy/control group are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study tested healthy adult participants (n=10, mean age 25) using an fMRI Face Matching Task focused on perception of others’ emotional (fear vs neutral) faces, which is a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports univariate whole-brain GLM analyses at the group level (first- and second-level contrasts; one-sample t-tests; results referenced in Supplementary Table S2 and Figures S1–S3), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is empirical original fMRI work in healthy adults and not limited to ROI-only, seed-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (honesty/trust) in healthy adults (N=31; mean age ~24). The task is social (take-advice game and subsequent trust game) probing perception/understanding of others and trust-related behavior. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses and contrasts (e.g., honesty vs dishonesty; value contrasts) with voxelwise thresholds and FWE cluster correction, and lists whole-brain activation loci (PCC, DLPFC, IPS, VMPFC, OFC, striatum, ACC). Although it also includes MVPA and PPI, whole-brain task-evoked univariate maps for the healthy sample are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adult participants (ages within 17–65) using task-evoked data and appropriate behavioral paradigms, the manuscript’s reported analyses are multivariate (within-ROI MVPA) and ROI-based. The full text does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map or coordinate table for the healthy group that would meet the inclusion requirement. The paper uses an individual-subject ToM localizer to define ROIs (first-level contrasts) but does not report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain activation map for the main task contrasts. Because the review requires at least one group-level whole-brain task activation map from the healthy/control group, this study fails that criterion and must be excluded.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI of a social-related process (emotional prosody/social communication), includes a healthy adult control group reported separately (fMRI sample: 21 controls, ages 20–46 within 17–65), and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation results for the control group (e.g., emotional vs. neutral prosody, complexity and condition contrasts), corrected for multiple comparisons and presented as cluster results/conjunction maps. Although ROI and PPI analyses are also reported, whole-brain task activations for controls are clearly described, so the study is not excluded by ROI-only or connectivity-only criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using task-based social judgment paradigms (approachability and intelligence judgments from faces) in healthy adult participants (47 healthy controls; ages mean within 17–65). Whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses are reported separately for healthy males and females (within-group contrasts: social vs gender judgments), with voxelwise statistical maps, cluster-level inference, peak coordinates, tables/figures, and regression analyses with empathy scores. A clinical ASD group is also analyzed, but healthy-control results are reported independently. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked group results) and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only).

The study is task-based fMRI in healthy adults (n=21, mean age 24) investigating action observation/execution and learned shape-action mappings—constructs directly related to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (mirror-system/social processing). It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses (a whole-brain second analysis at p<0.001 uncorrected with SPM maps and coordinate tables) in addition to ROI analyses. The healthy adult group results are reported and generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6±5.7) that directly probes social processing (person perception and person knowledge; bodies vs names; trait vs neutral statements). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names, Traits>Neutral, and the interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction; results are described in the main text, figures, and supplementary tables with coordinates. Although the study also presents PPI connectivity analyses, it clearly includes whole-brain univariate activation maps from the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria (task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults with group-level whole-brain results).

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task fMRI of social-related processing (self- vs other-referential valenced task; VV-SORP-T) relevant to perception/understanding of self and others. (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (women age 18–52; N=20) within the 17–65 range. (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked results (SPM8 GLM contrasts vs fixation and between conditions) with voxel-wise p-values and cluster thresholds, tables/figures and coordinate reporting; not limited to ROI-only results. (4) Empirical original fMRI data (task-based). No exclusion criteria are violated (not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are presented). Therefore INCLUDE.

This is an empirical fMRI study of healthy adults (N=18, ages 19–29) that investigates self-referential social cognition (conceptual vs. agentic self-processing). The task explicitly probes perception/understanding of the self and others. Group-level, voxelwise task-evoked analyses are reported, including whole-brain results (whole-brain FWE-corrected activations are reported and tables/figures/localizations are provided) alongside ROI/SVC analyses. The healthy participant group is within the 17–65 range and results are presented for this group. The paper is not resting-state or connectivity-only and contains univariate task activation contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (perception of fearful faces with direct vs. averted gaze). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, mean age 23.7) reported separately from the ASD group. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses for the control group (within-group contrasts such as AVERTED>DIRECT and AVERTED>FIXATION), with voxelwise statistical maps and corrected results described and visualized. Although a clinical group is also included, the healthy control whole-brain task effects are explicitly reported, satisfying inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (attentional orienting to gaze vs. arrow cues with social voice vs. tone), involving healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 22.95). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (2×2×2 factorial ANOVA) with whole-brain results and tables of activations (MNI coordinates) and appropriate corrections (FWE), as well as ROI/SVC results; results are clearly from the healthy/control sample. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (altruism task) in healthy adult participants (N=55; subset N=37 also completed food task; ages ~28), meeting the sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain analyses: GLMs were estimated at the first level and random-effects group analyses were performed; multivariate whole-brain searchlight decoding maps and cluster-level FWE-corrected group results are reported (with coordinates and cluster statistics for regions including TPJ, precuneus, VMPFC, DLPFC). Results are presented as group-level effects generalizable to healthy adults (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The study is empirical, not ROI-only or resting-state, and reports whole-brain task activation/decoding maps and coordinates. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social gaze and action control in healthy adults (N=30, mean age 24), meeting the sample criterion. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others via direct vs averted gaze) and uses task-evoked BOLD fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., incongruent vs congruent; direct vs averted) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also includes PPI connectivity analyses, those are supplementary to and do not replace the reported whole-brain activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the review.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (animacy/’like-me’ cues) in healthy adults (final N=23, mean age 26.4). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (main effects of agent form and belief, and interactions), with voxelwise thresholds and tables/coordinates described and visualized. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity, and results are presented for the healthy subject group rather than a clinical subgroup. Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task; (2) healthy adult sample within 17–65; (3) whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked maps clearly reported. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore I include this study in the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (empathy-for-pain) including a healthy adult control group (n=18; ages within 22–63). The paper reports whole-brain analyses and group-level task contrasts (see Supplementary Table 1) with coordinates and statistics (e.g., left anterior insula activation for pain empathy and contrasts between alexithymia groups), and also reports control vs. autism group comparisons across the whole brain. Thus it provides univariate, whole-brain task-evoked results that are attributable to healthy adults and meet the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult controls (n=8, mean age ~23) who listened to prosodic connected speech—a social-communication-related stimulus (prosody/Pragmatics falls under Social Communication). Group-level whole-brain, voxelwise analyses for the control group are reported (one-sample t-tests, conjunctions, and between-group contrasts; thresholds and cluster correction reported; anatomical localization provided), meeting the whole-brain evidence criterion. Although the paper also includes an HFA group, results for the healthy control group are reported separately. The study is empirical, within the 17–65 adult range, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although this fMRI study examines social-cognitive processes (action understanding/ToM) and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper does not report an unmasked whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The reported neuroimaging results are primarily between-group contrasts (ALS > HC and HC > ALS), conjunction counts, and some small-volume/ROI analyses; no clearly identified, generalizable healthy-group whole-brain one-sample (within-group) activation map (or equivalent coordinates/tables labeled as the healthy-group task effect) is provided. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group-level whole-brain task-evoked map for healthy adults. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of face-to-face eye-contact (social interaction) using dyadic fMRI in healthy adults (19 pairs; 38 participants; ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level voxelwise GLM analyses and paired t-tests (task A vs B; exogenous/endogenous contrasts) with whole-brain statistical maps (thresholds reported, cluster sizes, Z-scores, MNI coordinates and atlas labels). Whole-brain voxelwise results are described and presented (figures, probabilistic atlas label distributions, cluster tables), satisfying the requirement for univariate, group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps for healthy adults. The task probes social processes (reciprocal eye contact/mentalization). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore include.

This fMRI study uses a social-related task (self- and other-reflection) tapping Perception/Understanding of Self and Others. It includes a healthy control group of adults within the target age range and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts for the control group (e.g., Self>Facts, Other>Facts, Other>Self) with cluster results and MNI coordinates described in the text and figures. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses and healthy-group activation maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (final n=19, ages 18–35) using a social-related/self-processing paradigm (participants rated ‘self’- vs ‘non-self’-peptide odours). Group-level, univariate second-level analyses were performed (SPM) and activation coordinates are reported in MNI space. The manuscript states that whole-brain analysis was performed and reports voxelwise activation coordinates (right middle frontal cortex) and significance values; supplementary materials reportedly list additional olfactory activations. Thus it meets: (1) social-related task (perception/understanding of self), (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked results with reported coordinates. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample) prevent inclusion.

This study reports task-based fMRI measuring social perception of faces (viewing disfigured vs. corrected faces during a gender-judgement task), which fits social-related processing (Perception/Understanding of Others). Sample includes a healthy adult group (N=31; ages 18–35) with results reported separately. The paper provides whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (SnPM non-parametric group contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and reports significant clusters in occipito-temporal cortex and anterior cingulate—i.e., whole-brain task-evoked maps/contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses are not limited to ROIs nor to connectivity or resting-state only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This empirical study uses task-based fMRI to investigate multisensory processing of social non-verbal vocalizations and faces, a clear social-related construct (social communication/perception). The fMRI sample comprises healthy adults (fMRI group n=10, ages 24–37), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level voxelwise analyses (voxel-by-voxel two-tailed t tests, percent signal change maps transformed to Talairach space, cluster correction via AlphaSim) including condition-versus-rest and AV versus unisensory contrasts and presents whole-brain activation maps and ROI results derived from those maps. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results and provides univariate task-evoked whole-brain statistical maps for the healthy group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=29 in fMRI sample; mean age 25.6) that probes social-related processing (learning about and simulating others’ preferences, social influence, mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (second-level random-effects GLM; cluster-level FWE correction) with reported coordinates and significant clusters (e.g., mPFC [−12,53,1], visual cortex, pMFC, insula, striatum). Analyses are task-evoked (probe and choice trials) rather than ROI-only or resting-state/seed-connectivity only. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI study in healthy adults that includes social tasks (theory-of-mind and social attribution-of-attention), the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-activation map for the healthy group. The analyses center on localized (TPJ) group ICA and regression of component time courses within an ROI, plus seed-to-voxel connectivity maps. These component/ROI-based results and connectivity analyses do not constitute a whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrast (GLM) required by the inclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion requirement.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult women (ages 21–46) that uses a task in which participants view erotic pictures and videos of other people (male, female, same-sex couples). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (one-sample contrasts within each healthy orientation group; male vs. female stimuli) with corrected thresholds and cluster reports/figures and coordinate information, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample is healthy adults and results for these groups are reported separately. The task involves perception of others and social cues (faces, bodies, interpersonal sexual interactions) and the authors interpret activations in regions linked to social-cognitive processing (e.g., supramarginal/angular gyri, precuneus), which aligns with the review’s broad definition of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (cooperation/competition, self–other representations). Sample: healthy adult participants (final N=24, ages 19–31). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (GLMs identifying pgACC and area 9 as tracking self- and other-performance signals), with whole-brain results used to define ROIs and reported in the text/figures. The design and analyses are within the healthy adult range and not limited to a clinical subgroup; results for the healthy group are clearly reported. The study is empirical, reports original fMRI data, and is not ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI in healthy adults (n=30 females, age 19–39) examining social-related processing (kinship, moral dilemma, mentalizing). Reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses: inter-subject correlation (ISC) whole-brain maps and a GLM whole-brain contrast for the moral-dilemma decision task with cluster correction and tables of clusters/coordinates; unthresholded maps deposited in NeuroVault. Not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy-group results are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria violated.

Although this fMRI study probes social-related processing (personal familiarity of faces/places implicating perception/understanding of others and self) and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate contrasts for the healthy control group, the healthy participants are described as “healthy elderly” and the study context focuses on aging/aMCI. The review’s sample inclusion requires healthy adults aged 17–65. The paper does not provide explicit ages for controls and repeatedly frames them as elderly, implying they are outside the 17–65 range. Therefore it fails the age-sample inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–51) using a social-related task: emotional prosody comprehension distinguishing simple and complex (including social) emotions, which falls under Social Communication and Perception/Understanding of Others. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level analyses (one-sample t-tests and contrasts, SPM8; cluster-wise correction across the whole brain) with reported statistical maps and described activations for emotional vs. neutral and complex vs. simple contrasts. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes a clearly reported healthy adult group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target), samples healthy adults (32 males aged 21–33; task fMRI reported for 21 participants within the age range), and reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (paired-sample t-test and whole-brain covariate analyses) with FDR-corrected results. Although ROI analyses are also presented, they do not replace the presence of whole-brain task activation maps. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of social perception (point-light and human-like walkers) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (main effects and interactions) with stereotactic coordinates and FWE-corrected thresholds, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Results pertain to the healthy adult sample and are generalizable within the stated age range. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study is an fMRI investigation of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (N=36) and addresses social-processing constructs, the reported neuroimaging results were analyzed within a predefined bilateral vACC ROI using small-volume correction. The paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation map or whole-brain contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Because inclusion requires at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map, this study fails that requirement and should be excluded.

This is an empirical task-fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adults (N=20; ages 18–29). The task probes social-related processing (impression formation, social judgment of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (a whole-brain multilevel model and ROI follow-ups) with tables/coordinates and cluster results (DLPFC, dACC, etc.), i.e., task-evoked healthy-group activation maps. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical work. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

The study is an fMRI task in healthy adult participants and addresses social processing (empathy for pain). However, based on the provided full text, the paper reports whole-brain results only for between-group contrasts (STRESS > CONTROL and conjunctions thereof). I find no clear report of a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map (e.g., within-group or main-effect INJECTION>QTIP or BIOPSY>QTIP) identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The exclusion criteria state studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect should be excluded. Because the supplied text does not present a healthy-group whole-brain task map, the study does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (contrast of social vs. non-social images during an appraisal task), sample comprises healthy adults (N=14 analyzed; ages 23–50 within 17–65), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (social–nonsocial t-statistic maps with voxelwise thresholds and FDR correction, conjunction and whole-brain results described). Whole-brain results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Although the independent sample is small (noted in paper), that does not violate inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI during a clearly social-related paradigm (Social Feedback task tapping social evaluation/inclusion and exclusion). The sample are healthy adolescents/young adults (N=56 analyzed; age range 17–20), which falls within the review’s adult age range (≥17). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunction) with conservative FWE whole-brain correction and provides coordinates/overlay analyses. It is not ROI-only, nor limited to connectivity-only results. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study that used a face-localizer (faces vs objects and textures) and reports group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (Face>Object, Face>Texture) analyzed with FLAME and cluster correction. The sample includes a clearly reported healthy adult group (n=51, ages 18–42) analyzed separately from children. Results include whole-brain statistical maps and ROI-definitions derived from adult group contrasts; group-level activation tables/figures are described. The task probes social-related processing (perception of others via face stimuli), fitting the review’s constructs (Perception and Understanding of Others). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting/connectivity-only, and healthy adult whole-brain task effects are reported).

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing in a healthy adult sample (faces, N=18) and reports group-level contrasts, the reported results are based on ROI/small-volume-corrected analyses. The Methods explicitly state that analyses were performed using small volume correction and ROI masks, and the Results repeatedly describe 'ROI analyses' and SVC-corrected activations. I find no clear report of an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map (e.g., whole-brain main effects or contrasts reported outside ROI/SVC). Therefore the paper fails the required inclusion criterion of reporting at least one whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) in a healthy adult sample (n=74). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (one-sample t-tests and ANOVA; whole-brain FWE-corrected results and Supplementary Table of task effects) derived from the healthy/control participants, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only findings. Healthy participants are explicitly described and results are presented as generalizable healthy-group task effects. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (fMRI social task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain group-level activation maps reported). Confidence is high though exact participant ages are not listed in the excerpt; participant descriptions indicate adults within the target range.

This is an fMRI study of empathy using a social task (modified Empathic Accuracy Task) in healthy adults (final fMRI sample n=34, mean age 24, range within 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (emotional > neutral, happy > sad, parametric modulation by empathic accuracy, time-series correlations with intensity ratings), using random-effects inference and FWE-corrected TFCE thresholding; peak clusters and tables are reported. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain univariate contrasts meeting inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (witnessing violent dyadic interactions) in healthy adults (N=15 males, age 23.6±4.1), satisfying the sample criterion (healthy adult participants within 17–65). The study reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (GLM contrasts versus baseline and focus-on-aggressor vs focus-on-victim) with cluster-size correction and voxelwise results described in the text (including amygdala, insula, EBA, ACC, STS, occipital pole, thalamus, red nucleus), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. Whole-brain contrasts and trait-modulated activations and connectivity are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-healthy or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study sample comprises male adolescents (age range 13–19) and does not report a separate healthy adult subgroup within the required 17–65 age range. Inclusion criterion requires at least one group of healthy adults (17–65) with group-level results reported separately; this is not met. Although the paper includes task fMRI and reports exploratory whole-brain task activation, these maps are not clearly presented as a whole-brain, univariate healthy/control-group task effect generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the sample-age criterion (and likely the healthy-group whole-brain reporting criterion) and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using a task-based imitate/observe emotional faces paradigm probing social perception/understanding of others. The sample consists of healthy adults (initial N=28, final analyzed N=20; ages 18–55), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: a general linear model (SPM8) whole-brain GLM is described and compared to task PLS results (Supplementary Figure 1), and voxelwise brain patterns from the PLS are reported and thresholded and rendered on standard space. The reported effects are within the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: study uses task-based fMRI probing social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception), sample consists of healthy adults (n=13, ages 22–38). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked analyses (exploratory one-sample random-effects contrast of all ToM conditions vs. non-ToM, with reported activation maps and coordinate peaks), which provides univariate whole-brain evidence generalizable to healthy adults. Although follow-up contrasts were focused on ROIs derived from the whole-brain map, the presence of the initial whole-brain group effect prevents exclusion for ROI-only reporting. Not excluded by other criteria (not resting-state, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only).

The study uses task fMRI of emotion-word processing (a social/emotion-related construct) and includes a healthy adult control group; however, it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The paper’s whole-brain results are primarily between-group contrasts (controls > ASC) and pooled across all participants, while within-control analyses are reported as ROI statistics rather than whole-brain voxelwise maps. Per the meta-analysis rules, studies that provide only between-group contrasts (without an accompanying unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task effect) must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others’ pupillary signals) in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22). The task involves viewing dynamic eye stimuli with pupil-size biofeedback, which is a social-perception paradigm. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (main effects and interactions), with voxelwise statistical maps and reported coordinates and thresholds (whole-brain corrected for main effect; uncorrected voxelwise clusters reported for pupil-change effects), not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. Results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, age within 17–65). Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (dynamic direct vs averted gaze), a social-related task relevant to perception/understanding of others. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=25 typical males) with group-level within-group contrasts reported (e.g., controls: direct > averted gaze) and coordinates/tables described. Although main hypothesis testing used a priori ROI small-volume correction for ToM regions, the paper also reports whole-brain, FWE-corrected task contrasts (faces vs null) and provides peak coordinates and separate analyses for the control group. Thus the study provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked results identifiable as coming from the healthy adult group and meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (Thatcher Illusion face discrimination probing social/emotional and mentalizing processing and eye-region attention). The paper includes a healthy adult control group (neurotypical controls; n=18 analyzed, mean age 25.8 years) with results reported separately. The manuscript reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts/activation maps for the healthy (NT) group (within-group upright vs. inverted contrasts, whole-brain thresholds and cluster correction described; figures and tables of activation described). The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor to between-group contrasts without healthy-group maps. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and the work provides whole-brain, task-evoked activations generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (Cyberball social exclusion), includes a healthy adult control group (female adults), and reports whole-brain, univariate within-group task effects for the healthy controls (main effect of condition in left anterior insula/IFG reported at voxelwise FWE-corrected p<0.05). Results for the healthy group are described at the whole-brain level (not ROI- or connectivity-only), making them suitable for meta-analysis of healthy adult social processing. Note: the sample is female-only and exact ages are not listed in the text provided, but participants are described as adults (euthymic females), which is consistent with the 17–65 range. Therefore I include the study.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody) in healthy adults (N=22, mean age 27). It reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with conservative voxelwise and cluster-level FWE thresholds (voxel P<0.0001, cluster P<0.05), and these whole-brain activations are described in the text, figures, and tables. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range, and results are reported for the healthy participant group (no clinical-only reporting). The paper also reports connectivity (PPI) but crucially includes univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps, not ROI-only or resting-state–only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

While this is an fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of faces varying in race and status) in a healthy adult sample (N=60, mean age 23.8), the paper’s primary neuroimaging results are multivariate (behavioral PLS) and supplemental PLS of a control task. The manuscript describes GLM preprocessing and states that an earlier univariate analysis of these data exists elsewhere, but the present paper does not report any group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked univariate statistical maps (nor tables of coordinates) for the healthy/control group. Inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported group-level whole-brain univariate task activation map. Because this criterion is not met in the full text provided, the study must be excluded from the meta-analysis despite meeting other criteria (task type and sample).

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants viewed cooperative and affective social interactions (social intention understanding). Sample: 27 healthy right-handed adults (ages ~24.9–26.3), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (full-factorial, conjunctions, direct contrasts) with thresholds including p<0.05 FWE-corrected and coordinate/figure reporting of activation foci (TPJ, vmPFC, premotor regions). Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses an fMRI face-processing task with healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain voxelwise analyses in the discovery sample, the voxelwise analyses were performed on a combined sample of patients and controls and the paper does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The independent replication sample of healthy adults used an anatomical ROI approach (FFA) rather than whole-brain maps. Therefore the paper does not meet the requirement to report at least one whole-brain, group-level task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group and must be excluded.

This paper reports task-evoked fMRI in healthy adult samples (study 1: n=41, study 2: n=39; ages 18–24) and examines social-related constructs (self-related processing, mentalizing/social cognition, valuation of sharing). The authors conducted group-level random-effects whole-brain analyses (exploratory whole-brain searches, thresholding and multiple-comparison correction reported, and whole-brain tables/clusters described), and report univariate task-evoked maps and contrasts generalizable to the healthy adult groups. The study is empirical, not clinical-only, and presents whole-brain activation results for healthy participants; it does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (control aversion/social cognition) using an incentive-compatible decision task during fMRI. (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=51, mean age 22, right-handed students, 17–65 range). (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates (e.g., right IPL 39 −40 40), i.e., voxelwise maps generalizable to healthy adults. (4) Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses; whole-brain activation contrasts are explicitly reported. No exclusion criteria (clinical-only sample, ROI-only, resting-state-only, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social self-processing (direct and reflected self-evaluations), which falls under social-related constructs (Perception and Understanding of Self). It includes a healthy adult sample reported separately (N=19; ages 22–31). The authors performed whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (SPM8; 2×4×3 ANOVA with voxel-wise p<0.005 and cluster-extent FWE correction via AlphaSim) and report group-level effects and contrasts; supplementary materials provide separate adult and adolescent analyses. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social perception task (trustworthiness and fear appraisal of faces) relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others. The sample includes a healthy adult group (N=17, ages 18–45) reported separately from a BPD clinical group. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (parametric regressions and task contrasts) with cluster-level results and coordinates (described in main text and supplementary tables/figures), not limited to ROI-only analyses. Results include within-group effects (e.g., amygdala modulation by fearfulness in controls) and whole-brain contrasts (fearfulness vs trustworthiness, trustworthiness-specific cortical activations) that are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state/seed-only, age range OK, healthy-group whole-brain results provided). Therefore study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–30) using a social-processing task (eye-gaze perception). It reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain second-level analyses (GLM with AQ as regressor) and presents task-evoked statistical maps and coordinates (thresholded at p<0.05 FDR whole-brain and cluster extent), fulfilling the requirement for whole-brain univariate task activation generalizable to a healthy adult population. The design, preprocessing, and random-effects analyses are described in detail and results are reported for within-group contrasts (variable vs. constant gaze and related comparisons). The paper is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Although the sample consists of healthy adults (age 18–27) and the paradigm concerns social processing (receiving criticism), the study reports only resting-state, seed-based functional connectivity contrasts (criticism > standard) and cluster/second-level connectivity maps. It does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map for the healthy group. Per exclusion criteria, studies that report only resting-state or seed-based connectivity analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation are ineligible for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of healthy adult participants (17–65): 17 nulliparous women aged 19–29. The task probes social-related processing (perception of infant cries and facial affect—affiliation/attachment, social communication, perception of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects analyses with voxelwise maps, cluster thresholds, FWE correction, tables/figures of activations and coordinate-based results for contrasts in the healthy sample. No ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only limitation is present, and results for the healthy group are reported separately. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social action (gesture) planning and execution, a social-communication process. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) with results reported separately. The authors report whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (within-group and between-group contrasts) for planning and execution conditions, with within-group control results described and presented in figures/tables (whole-brain thresholds noted). Thus it provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults and meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria. Minor uncertainty about exact participant ages (not listed in the excerpt) reduces confidence slightly, but recruitment from staff/students and matching suggests an adult sample within 17–65.

execution_stats.search_query: ( ('functional MRI'[Title/Abstract] OR 'functional magnetic resonance imaging'[Title/Abstract] OR 'fMRI'[Title/Abstract] ) AND ( 'social communication'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social processing'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social interaction'[Title/Abstract] OR 'affiliation'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social attachment'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social cognition'[Title/Abstract] OR 'understanding others'[Title/Abstract] ) AND 'Humans'[MeSH])
